Il est un cultivateur dans le village d’Ahovilèkomè de la vallée de l’Ouémé et est membre du groupement GH AYIDOTE MINAWANOU DE HOUEDOME. Les habitants de ce village font les travaux champêtres après la décrue du fleuve ouémé. Leurs terres sont riches et les offrent un bon rendement.  Leurs spéculations principales sont la culture du maïs, du piment, des légumes, du gombo, de la tomate et du manioc. Le problème de ces habitants riverains du fleuve est que, en période de crue, ils n’ont plus d’activité et dépensent tout le revenu issu de la campagne écoulée à la consommation. A la décrue ils n’ont plus d’argent pour payer la main d’œuvre indispensable pour emblaver la superficie à eux disponible.  La pratique dans le milieu qui consiste au bradage des récoltes ne les sécurise pas et les runes d’avantage. Cette pratique est la vente à un prix dérisoire de la récolte future a un nantis pour disposer de la somme nécessaire aux travaux champêtres. Fatigués de cette pratique ils ont sollicité un prêt de 100 000 FCFA pour l’exploitation d’environ 1hectares des spéculations susse indiquées.
texts.en:
Born around 1963 in the Houedome district of Dangbo village, Mr. Benoît Degnibe is married and has eight children, five of whom attend school. He is a farmer in Ahovilèkomè village in the Ouémé valley and he is a member of the Houedome group GH AYIDOTE MINAWANOU. The inhabitants of this village farm the land after the level of the Ouémé river drops. Their lands are rich and highly productive. Their main business activities involve growing corn, peppers, vegetables, okra, tomatoes and manioc. The problem for these river valley dwellers is that, during the flood period, they no longer have anything to do and they spend all the income generated from the sale of their harvested produce. At low water they don’t have any money left to pay the workforce that is essential for sowing the land available to them. The local practice of selling off the harvested crops does not provide them with security, moreover, it bankrupts them. This practice involves selling the future harvest at a rock-bottom price to an affluent person to get hold of the money required to carry out the farming. Tired of this practice, they have asked for a loan of 100,000 FCFA ($200) to farm about one hectare of the aforementioned land.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To farm one hectare of corn and peppers

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. is currently in the brewing business and is requesting a loan to expand her business.  Mary is 30 years old and is married. Her husband is a soldier. She has four children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a big bar.


BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services. These programs and services are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open a bar

loans.name: Julia

texts.es: Julia tiene 25 años de edad, vive junto a su hijo y a su conviviente quienes la apoyan en todo, sobre todo en sus propósitos para la mejora de su negocio. Se dedica a la venta de ropa usada, la lleva a vender por los distintos caseríos de su localidad, dejándola al crédito o al contado, esta labor la viene realizando desde hace ya dos años atrás, y lo que le gusta de su trabajo es conocer muchos lugares y dar una muy buena atención a sus clientes. Le es rentable porque las prendas que vende son solo por pedidos, debido a ya cuenta con sus clientes selectos. Este es su 2do préstamo con MFP, y ha demostrado ser responsable con sus pagos. Con el dinero que solicita comprará más prendas, posteriormente quiere alquilar un puesto en el mercado para poner su tienda.
texts.en:
Julia is 25 years old and lives with her son and husband, who help her with everything, especially the improvement of her business. She sells used clothing, which she carries to different villages in her area to sell for credit or cash, and has been doing so for the past two years. What she likes about her work is getting to know many places and giving her customers a lot of attention. It is profitable because the garments are sold only through orders, already selected by the customers. This is her second loan from MFP, and she has demonstrated responsibility with her payments. With this money, she will buy more garments, and later she would like to rent a space in the market for her store.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase the quantity of garments for sale

loans.name: Jean

texts.fr: Né vers 1953 dans l’arrondissement de HOUEDOME de la commune de DANGBO, monsieur  A. Jean est marié et père de 5 enfants dont 4 scolarisés. Il est un cultivateur du village d’Ahovilèkomè de la vallée de l’Ouémé et est membre du groupement GH AYIDOTE MINAWANOU DE HOUEDOME. Tired of this practice, they have asked for a loan of 100,000 FCFA ($200) to farm about one hectare of the aforementioned land

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To farm one hectare of corn and peppers

loans.name: Svetlana

texts.en:
Svetlana is married and raises three daughters in the city of Kamenka. Svetlana sells food items, such as tea, coffee and fruits, in the local city market. Her vending kiosk is well known in the market as she owns big fridges with a nice selection of well preserved products. Moreover, she always offers a warm smile to all her customers. Svetlana has been in this business for 10 years.

She has benefited from receiving eight previous loans from Nadiya Ukraine. Presently, Svetlana has about 100,000 Grivnas invested in her business. Her income is about 7,000-8,000 Grivnas a month. Svetlana would like to buy more fresh fruit before the upcoming holiday season, as fruits are always a popular item during the Christmas holiday in Ukraine. Svetlana is requesting a loan of 3,000 Grivnas that she hopes to repay in two months. 

One of her long-term plans is to build her own little store. She has already purchased a land lot to start construction work.

loans.use: To purchase fresh fruit for the holiday season

loans.name: Abraham

texts.fr: Né vers 1948 dans l’arrondissement de HOUEDOME de la commune de DANGBO, monsieur  D. Abraham est marié et père de 8 enfants dont 4 scolarisés. Il est un cultivateur dans le village d’Ahovilèkomè de la vallée de l’Ouémé et est membre du groupement GH AYIDOTE MINAWANOU DE HOUEDOME. Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To farm one hecatre of corn and peppers

loans.name: Karina

texts.es: Karina tiene 36 años de edad, es viuda, vive con sus tres hijos que estudian y la quieren mucho. Ella se dedica  a la venta de abarrotes y productos de primera necesidad, en las instalaciones de su domicilio, donde implementó un espacio para su bodega, este negocio lo inició hace 2 años atrás, y lo que le gusta de su trabajo es dar una muy buena atención a sus clientes, ya que de eso depende que regresen a comprar sus productos. Le es rentable debido a que tiene una clientela que continuamente consumen sus productos. Este es su 5to préstamo con MFP, y ha demostrado ser responsable con sus pagos. Con el dinero solicitado comprará más productos para implementar su negocio y posteriormente ampliarlo y ambientarlo mejor.
texts.en:
Karina is a 36-year-old widow who lives with her three school-aged children that love her a lot. She dedicates herself to selling groceries and other necessities out of her home, where she arranged a space for her store. She began this business two years ago, and what she likes about her job is providing very good service to her customers, since their decision to return to buy her goods depends on it. Her business is profitable since she has a customer base that continually consumes her products. This is her fifth loan with MFP and she has proven to be responsible in her payments. With the money requested, she will buy more products to stock her store, and later to expand it and improve its atmosphere.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expand the merchandise in her grocery store.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther  S.  sells charcoal and is requesting a loan to expand her business.  Esther is 28 years old and is married. Her husband is a driver. She has three children. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services. These programs and services are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Open up a shop

loans.name: Keily

texts.es: Keily tiene 34 años de edad, es madre de dos hijos, vive junto a su conviviente quien está de acuerdo con todos sus propósitos de mejora de su negocio. Ella es propietaria de un motocarro, lo tiene desde hace un año atrás, es usada para brindar servicio de transporte público, y es manejado por su esposo, quien también se encarga de cuidarlo. Se encuentra contenta y satisfecha porque su motocarro le genera buenos ingresos y como ella misma administra las ganancias, solo utiliza para los gastos familiares necesarios, y le deja un margen de ganancias muy bueno. Este es su 3er préstamo con MFP, y ha demostrado ser responsable con sus pagos. Con el dinero solicitado quiere comprar repuestos para mandar a reparar la moto, para que trabaje adecuadamente.
texts.en:
Keily is 34 years old and the mother of two children. She lives with her partner who completely agrees with all of her plans to improve her business. She is the owner of a motorbike, which she has had for a year, and she uses it to provide public transportation. Her husband drives it, and he also is in charge of maintaining it. She is satisfied and content because her motorbike brings in a good income and as she herself administers their earnings, she only uses it for the family's necessary expenses, which leaves her a very good earnings margin. This is her third loan with MFP and she has proven herself responsible in her payments. With the money requested, she wants to buy spare parts to repair the bike so that it works properly.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase spare parts to repair her motorbike.

loans.name: Lleysi

texts.es: Lleysi tiene 36 años, vive junto a su conviviente y a sus cuatro hijos que estudian. Ella se dedica a la venta de “Juanes” (arroz con pollo, aceitunas y huevo envuelto en una hoja), desde hace 3 años atrás, los lleva a vender de manera ambulante por los diferentes lugares de su zona, lo que le gusta de su trabajo es que conoce muchos lugares y muchas personas con quienes comparte muchos diálogos. Le es muy rentable, ya que cuenta con sus clientes quienes esperan todas las mañanas a la vendedora de juanes para hacerle el consumo. Le va muy bien. Es su primer préstamo con MFP, por lo que se compromete a ser puntual en sus cuotas. Con el dinero solicitado quiere mandar a construir un kiosco para poder vender más cómodamente sus Juanes.
texts.en:
Lleysi is 36 years old, and lives with her partner and their four school-aged children. She dedicates herself to selling "Juanes", a dish made of rice with chicken, olives, and eggs wrapped in a leaf. For the last three years she has worked by selling these, traveling through different neighborhoods in her area. What she likes best about her job is that she gets to know a lot of places and talk with a lot of people. The business is very profitable for her since she has customers that wait for the Juanes seller every morning so they can eat her food. It's going very well for her. This is her first loan with MFP, so she has committed herself to being punctual in her payments. With the money requested, she wants to have a kiosk built so that she can sell her Juanes more comfortably.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build a kiosk to sell her Juanes

loans.name: Karim

texts.fr: Né vers 1978 dans l’arrondissement de HOUEDOME de la commune de DANGBO, monsieur   E. Karim est marié et père de 3 enfants dont 1 scolarisé. Il est un cultivateur dans le village d’Ahovilèkomè de la vallée de l’Ouémé et est membre du groupement GH AYIDOTE MINAWANOU DE HOUEDOME. Les habitants de ce village font les travaux champêtres à la décrue du fleuve ouémé. Leurs terres sont riches et les offrent un bon rendement.  Leurs spéculations principales sont la culture du maïs, du piment, des légumes, du gombo, de la tomate et du manioc. Le problème de ces habitants riverains du fleuve est que, en période de crue, ils n’ont plus d’activité et dépensent tout le revenu issu de la campagne écoulée à la consommation. A la décrue ils n’ont plus d’argent pour payer la main d’œuvre indispensable pour emblaver la superficie à eux disponible.  La pratique dans le milieu qui consiste au bradage des récoltes ne les sécurise pas et les runes d’avantage. Cette pratique est la vente à un prix dérisoire de la récolte future a un nantis pour disposer de la somme nécessaire aux travaux champêtres. Fatigués de cette pratique ils ont sollicité un prêt de 100 000 FCFA pour l’exploitation d’environ 1hectares des spéculations susse indiquées.
texts.en:
Mr. Karim E. was born around 1978 in the HOUEDOME district in the town of DANGBO. He is married and the father of three children, one of whom attends school. He is a farmer in Ahovilèkomè village in the Ouémé valley and is a member of the HOUEDOME group GH AYIDOTE MINAWANOU. The inhabitants of this village work the land after the fall of the level of the Ouémé river. Their land is rich and offers a high yield. Their main activity is growing corn, peppers, vegetables, okra, tomatoes and manioc. The problem for these riverside residents is that, during the flood period, they no longer have anything to do and spend all the income generated from the sale of their harvested produce. When the river level drops they do not have any money left to pay for the workforce essential for sowing the available land. The local practice of selling cheaply the harvest does not provide them with financial security and further bankrupts them. This practice involves selling the future harvest at a rock-bottom price to an affluent person in order to have the required money to continue farming. Tired of this practice, they are requesting a loan of 100 000 FCFA (USD 200) to farm about one hectare of the aforementioned land.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To farm one hectare of corn and peppers

loans.name: Maria

texts.es: Maria tiene 28 años de edad, vive junto a su conviviente y su pequeña hija a quien adora mucho. Ella se dedica desde hace 2 años atrás a la venta de productos de belleza como perfumes, shampoo, talcos, lápiz labiales, correctores para uñas, etc., ya  que es  una mujer muy activa y con deseos de superación, lo que le gusta de su trabajo es buscar la forma de convencer a sus clientes para poder vender sus productos y dar una muy buena atención es lo primordial, nos menciona. Le es muy rentable porque ella se ha ganado con este trabajo una gran gama de clientes, por lo que le va excelente. Es su primer préstamo con MFP. Con el dinero solicitado quiere comprar más productos de belleza, además una pequeña vitrina para ponerlos dentro y estén más seguros.
texts.en:
Maria is 28 years old and lives with her partner and their small daughter, whom she adores very much. She has been selling beauty products—perfume, shampoo, body powder, lipstick, nail polish corrector pens, etc.—for 2 years because she is a very active woman who wants to get ahead. What she likes most about her job is looking for a way to persuade her customers to buy her products, and she notes that providing excellent customer service is essential. This business is very lucrative for her because she has established a sold client-base, which is why she has prospered. This is her first loan with MFP. With the money that she is requesting, she would like to purchase more beauty products and a small glass display case in which to place her products so that they can be protected.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase beauty products

loans.name: Maria

texts.es: María tiene 40 años de edad, vive junto a sus 3 hijos que estudian y a su esposo quien la apoya mucho. Ella se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza, los lleva a vender por los  diferentes lugares de su zona, dejándolos al crédito o al contado, esta actividad la viene realizando hace un año atrás, y lo que le gusta de su trabajo es tratar directamente con sus clientes. Cuenta con una fiel clientela que requieren mucho de sus productos y le va bien. Este es su 6to préstamo con MFP, y ha demostrado ser responsable con sus pagos. Con el dinero que solicita quiere comprar más productos de belleza y así estoquear mejor su pequeña vitrina de exhibición.
texts.en:
Maria is a 40-year-old woman who lives with her 3 school age children and her husband, who gives her great support. She sells beauty products in the different sections of her district. She accepts payments in cash or credit for her products. She has been in this business for a year now, and what she likes about her job is dealing directly with her clientele. She has loyal customers who really need her products, so her business is prospering. This is her sixth loan with MFP, and she has demonstrated that she is responsible with her payments. With the loan that she is requesting, she will purchase more beauty products so that she can better stock her small display case.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase beauty products

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther M. sells food like chicken and cassava at a restaurant and is requesting a loan to expand her business.  Esther is 35 years old and is married. Her husband is a driver in the ministry of education. She has two children, both of whom attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to stock more food for sale at the restaurant. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services. These programs and services are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Akonagni

texts.fr: Né vers 1980 dans l’arrondissement de HOUEDOME de la commune de DANGBO, monsieur    D. Akonagni est marié et père de 5 enfants dont 3 scolarisé. Il est un cultivateur du village d’Ahovilèkomè de la vallée de l’Ouémé et est membre du groupement GH AYIDOTE MINAWANOU DE HOUEDOME. Les habitants de ce village font les travaux champêtres à la décrue du fleuve ouémé. Leurs terres sont riches et les offrent un bon rendement.  Leurs spéculations principales sont la culture du maïs, du piment, des légumes, du gombo, de la tomate et du manioc. Le problème de ces habitants riverains du fleuve est que, en période de crue, ils n’ont plus d’activité et dépensent tout le revenu issu de la campagne écoulée à la consommation. A la décrue ils n’ont plus d’argent pour payer la main d’œuvre indispensable pour emblaver la superficie à eux disponible.  La pratique dans le milieu qui consiste au bradage des récoltes ne les sécurise pas et les runes d’avantage. Cette pratique est la vente à un prix dérisoire de la récolte future a un nantis pour disposer de la somme nécessaire aux travaux champêtres. Fatigués de cette pratique ils ont sollicité un prêt de 100 000 FCFA pour l’exploitation d’environ 1hectares des spéculations susse indiquées.
texts.en:
Mr. Akonagni D. was born around 1980 in the HOUEDOME district in the town of DANGBO. He is married and the father of five children, three of whom attend school. He is a farmer in Ahovilèkomè village in the Ouémé valley and is a member of the HOUEDOME group GH AYIDOTE MINAWANOU. The inhabitants of this village work the land after the fall of the level of the Ouémé river. Their land is rich and offers a high yield. Their main activity is growing corn, peppers, vegetables, okra, tomatoes and manioc. The problem for these riverside residents is that, during the flood period, they no longer have anything to do and spend all the income generated from the sale of their harvested produce. When the river level drops they do not have any money left to pay for the workforce essential for sowing the available land. The local practice of selling cheaply the harvest does not provide them with financial security and further bankrupts them. This practice involves selling the future harvest at a rock-bottom price to an affluent person in order to have the required money to continue farming. Tired of this practice, they are requesting a loan of 100 000 FCFA (USD 200) to farm about 1 hectares of the aforementioned land.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To farm one hectare of corn and peppers.

loans.name: Yawo

texts.en:
Yawo K. is a 32-year-old man, who is married with 2 children. In the local language, Ewe, his first name indicates that he was born on Thursday. Yawo lives in the village of Wome, a small town approximately 130 kilometers from Lomé, the Togolese capital.

To provide for his family, Yawo picks up passengers along the road with his motorcycle and drops them off at their destination. This service is always in demand in Wome because there is no electricity in this village, and people must often travel further than walking distance to take care of business. Yawo has asked for this loan from Kiva, so he can buy a new motorcycle, which will permit him to improve his business. With the profits he will earn from his business, Yawo can continue to send his children to school and provide for his wife and family.

loans.use: Buy a new motorcycle

loans.name: Milagro Jamileth

texts.es: La  señora Milagro  está solicitando refinanciamiento de su 6to crédito para invertirlo en mejora de su vivienda (terminar de construir un cuarto), trabaja como docente en la Escuela  césar Augusto Salinas Pinell, tiene 2 hijos: el mayor es un docente mayor de edad y una  hija de 17 años que actualmente estudia en la escuela normal Gregorio Aguilar Barea,  Milagro cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo quien es un hombre trabajador que apesar de la dura situacion economica siempre esta apoyando a su familia, esta docente es una mujer responsable trabajadora y de buenas costumbres, profesa la religión evangelica, actualmente esta estudiando su 4to año en la universidad URACCAN Recinto Nueva Guinea. Ella se siente agradecida con la Institución de AFODENIC ya que con los créditos anteriores ha mejorado su vivienda en gran medida, su sueño es tener una vivienda con mejores condiciones y trabajo para así sacar a su familia adelante y ayudar a su madre comprandole sus medicamentos ya que es una ancianita que necesita tratamiento medico mensual.
texts.en:
Milagro is seeking to finance her 6th loan which she will invest in home improvements (specifically to finish a room she is building). She is an educator at the Cesar Augusto Salinas Pinell School. She has two children: the oldest is already grown and also works in education and she has a 17-year-old daughter who studies at the Gregorio Aguilar Barea School. Milagro has the support of her hard-working husband who always helps his family in spite of hard economic times. This teacher is a responsible, hard-working, Christian woman with good values. She is also in her fourth year at the URACCAN Recinto Nueva Guinea University. She is grateful for the AFODENIC institution--with her previous loans she was able to greatly improve her home. Her dream is to have a nice home and a job in order to help her family move forward. She also would like to help her elderly mother who needs monthly medical treatments.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buiding a room/ house addition

loans.name: Maritza

texts.es: Maritza tiene 50 años, es madre de 2 hijos, vive junto a su esposo que la apoya en todo lo posible. Desde hace un año se dedica a la venta de ropa para niños y adultos, su esposo, quien es trabajador independiente la apoya mucho en su negocio durante los momentos que le es factible. Ella se levanta muy temprano para preparar la comida del día, luego se lleva a vender su prendas por  los diferentes lugares de su zona. Le es muy rentable porque ya cuenta con una clientela selecta y le va muy bien. Es su primer préstamo con MFP, por lo que se compromete a ser puntual en sus cuotas. Con el dinero que solicita comprará más ropa, además mandará a construir en su propia casa un local, para poner su tienda de ropa.
texts.en:
Maritza is 50-year-old mother with 2 children. She lives with her husband, who supports her with everything he possibly can. For a year, she has been selling apparel for children and adults. Her husband, who is self-employed, helps her with the business whenever possible. She gets up very early in the morning to prepare the meals for the day, then goes to sell her garments in the different parts of her zone. The business is very lucrative because she has a solid client-base, which makes it prosper. This is her first loan with MFP, which is why she promises to be punctual with her monthly installments. With the money she is requesting, she will purchase more apparel, as well as have an office space built in her home so that she can set up her own clothing boutique.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build an office space for her business

loans.name: Nila

texts.es: Nila tiene 25 años de edad, es madre de una pequeña que está estudiando y es la razón para seguir adelante, vive con su conviviente quien la apoya mucho. Ella es propietaria de un motocarro,  el mismo que lo maneja su pareja, quien se dedica al transporte de pasajeros desde hace 2 años atrás. Lo que le gusta de este trabajo es que le ayuda mucho en sus gastos diaR. familiares. Le es rentable ya que ella es la encargada de administrar las ganancias diarias que recibe. Debido a la gran demanda de este tipo de transporte en la selva, tiene que lidiar con la competencia constantemente. Es la primera vez que solicita un préstamo con MFP. Con este dinero comprará repuestos para mandar a repara su moto.
texts.en:
Nila is 25 and has a little girl who is a student and her reason for forging ahead. She lives with her partner, who is very supportive of her. She owns an auto rickshaw, which her partner has used for the past two years to earn a living transporting passengers. What Nila likes about this work is that it helps her with the family’s day-to-day expenses. It is profitable since she is the one who manages the daily earnings. Because of the high demand for this type of transportation in the rainforest, she is continually up against competition. This is the first time she has requested a loan from MFP. She will use the money to purchase spare parts to maintain her auto rickshaw.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Maintenance of her auto rickshaw

loans.name: Jacob

texts.fr: Né vers 1963 dans l’arrondissement de HOUEDOME de la commune de DANGBO, monsieur L. Jacob  est marié et père de 6 enfants dont 3 scolarisés. Il est un cultivateur du village d’Ahovilèkomè de la vallée de l’Ouémé. Les habitants de ce village font les travaux champêtres à la décrue du fleuve Ouémé. Leurs terres sont riches et leur offrent un bon rendement.  Leurs spéculations principales sont la culture du maïs, du piment, des légumes, du gombo, de la tomate et du manioc. Le problème de ces habitants riverains du fleuve est que, en période de crue, ils n’ont plus d’activité et dépensent tout le revenu issu de la campagne écoulée à la consommation. A la décrue ils n’ont plus d’argent pour payer la main d’œuvre indispensable pour emblaver la superficie à eux disponible.  La pratique dans le milieu qui consiste au bradage des récoltes ne les sécurise pas et les ruines davantage. Cette pratique est la vente à un prix dérisoire de la récolte future à un nantis pour disposer de la somme nécessaire aux travaux champêtres. Fatigués de cette pratique ils ont sollicité un prêt pour l’exploitation d’environ un hectare des spéculations sus indiquées.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Exploitation d'un hectare  de maïs et de piment.

loans.name: Faustino Saul

texts.es: Don Faustino está solicitando refinanciamiento de su 3er crédito para  Terminar de construir  una habitación, trabaja como Responsable de insumos médicos del hospital Jacinto Hernández desde hace 18 años, en el que se ha desempeñado con gran resposalidad, es honesto, trabajador y muy querido por sus compañeros de trabajo, tiene 2 hijos: el mayor de 13 años estudia su 5to  grado de educación primaria y una niña de 9 años estudia su 4to grado de educación primaria, su esposa trabaja en el Gallo Mas Gallo, ambos son trabajadores asalariados, no dependen de otros ingresos, pero ambos comparten los gastos familiares, el se siente agradecido con la institución de AFODENIC  ya que con los anteriores ha comprado sus electrodomésticos, su sueño es tener salud para sus familia,  estabilidad laboral y poco a poco ir mejorando la infraestructura de su vivienda.
texts.en:
Faustino is starting his third loan cycle in order to finish building a room in his home. For the past 18 years he has worked as a manager of medical supplies at the Jacinto Hernandez Hospital, a job that he has carried out with responsibility and honesty. He is hard-working and loved by his colleagues. He has two children: the oldest is 13 years old and is in 5th grade and he has a daughter who is 9 years old and is in 4th grade. His wife works at Gallo Mas Gallo and both of them are salaried workers who do not have other income to depend on. They both share the family expenses and he feels grateful for AFODENIC. With his previous loans he has bought household appliances. He dream is for his family to be in good health, with stable work and to continue to improve the infrastructure of his house, little by little.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Building a room

loans.name: Rocio

texts.es: Rocio tiene 35 años de edad, es madre de 2 niños que estudian, vive junto a su conviviente quien siempre le da la mano en sus labores. Ella tiene un pequeño molino donde fabrica alimentos para pollos (purina), esta actividad la viene haciendo desde 4 años atrás, y lo que le gusta de su trabajo es que conoce a mucha gente con quienes imparte ideas de negocio mientras realiza sus ventas. Le es rentable porque su pequeño molino le produce más de lo que se podría imaginar, además será una de las primeras exportadoras de este producto en su zona, por lo que le va  muy bien. Este es su 5to préstamo con MFP, y ha demostrado ser responsable con sus pagos. Con el dinero que solicita comprará más insumos para la fabricación de su producto.
texts.en:
Rocio is 35 years old, is mother to two children who are studying, and lives together with her spouse who always gives her a hand with her work. She has a small mill where she manufactures chicken feed (purina), and has been doing this work for four years. What she likes about her work is that she gets to know many people who give her business ideas while she carries out her sales. The business is profitable because her small mill produces more for her than she could have imagined, and furthermore she will be one of the first exporters of this product in her zone, so it is going very well. This is her fifth loan with MFP and she has shown herself to be responsible with her payments. With the money she is requesting she will buy more raw ingredients to manufacture her product.

Translated from Spanish by Diane Lister, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase raw ingredients to make her product

loans.name: Christophe

texts.fr: Né vers 1971 dans l’arrondissement de KESSOUNOU de la commune de DANGBO, monsieur  B. M. Christophe est marié et père de 2 enfants dont 1 scolarisé. Il est un cultivateur dans le village de GLAHOUNSA de la vallée de l’Ouémé et est membre du groupement  GH MISSIMAHOU DE GLAHOUNSA. Les habitants de ce village font les travaux champêtres à la décrue du fleuve ouémé. Leurs terres sont riches et les offrent un bon rendement.  Leurs spéculations principales sont la culture du maïs, du piment, des légumes, du gombo, de la tomate et du manioc. texts.en:
Mr. Christophe M.B. was born around 1971 in the KESSOUNOU district in the town of DANGBO. He is married and the father of two children, one of whom attends school. He is a farmer in GLAHOUNSA village in the Ouémé valley and is a member of the HOUEDOME group GH MISSIMAHOU DE GLAHOUNSA. The inhabitants of this village work the land after the fall of the level of the Ouémé river. Their land is rich and offers a high yield. Their main activity is growing corn, peppers, vegetables, okra, tomatoes and manioc. The problem for these riverside residents is that, during the flood period, they no longer have anything to do and spend all the income generated from the sale of their harvested produce. When the river level drops they do not have any money left to pay for the workforce essential for sowing the available land. The local practice of selling cheaply the harvest does not provide them with financial security and further bankrupts them. This practice involves selling the future harvest at a rock-bottom price to an affluent person in order to have the required money to continue farming. Tired of this practice, they are requesting a loan of 140 000 FCFA (USD 275) to farm about 1.5 hectares of the aforementioned land.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Farming of 1.5 hectares of corn and peppers

loans.name: Roger

texts.es: Roger tiene 46 años de edad, es soltero, vive junto a su hermana quien siempre le da la mano en su negocio. El se dedica a la venta de ropa que lleva a vender por los distintos lugares de su localidad, la deja al contado o al crédito, esta labor la viene realizando desde hace un año y lo que le gusta de su trabajo es tener un trato directo con sus clientes y darles una buena atención. Le es rentable porque sus prendas de vestir son de muy buena calidad y sus clientes le compran con mucho gusto y constantemente. Es su primer préstamo con MFP, por lo que se compromete a ser puntual en sus cuotas. Con el dinero que solicita quiere alquilar un local para su tienda de ropa, además de comprar más prendas de vestir.
texts.en:
Roger is 46 years old, is single, and lives together with his sister who always gives him a hand in his business. He earns a living at selling clothing. He takes the clothing to retail at various places in his town, and leaves the clothing for cash or on credit. He has been doing this work for a year and what he likes about his work is having a direct contact with his clients and giving them good service. The work is profitable because his clothing is of very good quality and his clients buy constantly and with great pleasure. This is his first loan with MFP and so to him it is extra important that he be on time with his payments. With the money he is requesting he wants to rent a shop for his clothing store and also to buy more clothing.

Translated from Spanish by Diane Lister, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To rent premises to sell his clothing

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is married with two daughters. When she opened her small vending kiosk, her family was in a very tough financial situation. However, Irina decided to take a risk and start a small business that sells pet food, treats and accessories in the local market.  Presently, she has about 25,000 Grivnas in working capital and monthly income of around 8,000 Grivnas. 

Irina has been receiving loans from Nadiya Ukraine since 2001. She has promptly repaid each of the loans received from the organization. Irina is asking for a loan of 3,000 Grivnas to increase her inventory. She is planning to purchase a variety of pet supplies such as feeders, bowls, mats, collars, leashes, toys, and canned/dry pet food. She believes a good assortment of supplies for dogs, cats, birds, small animals and fish will meet the needs of more pet owners, helping them find the right product for their pets. This loan will not only help Irina re-stock her inventory and boost her sales, but it will also help her earn enough to support her family and provide a better livelihood for them.
This is a short-term seasonal loan that will be repaid in two months.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Rosana

texts.es: Rosana tiene 41 años de edad, es madre de una niña y otro bebe que viene en camino, ella vive junto a su conviviente, quien la ayuda mucho, sobre todo en su negocio. Ella se dedica a vender abarrotes y productos de primera necesidad dentro de su vivienda, lo que le gusta de su labor es vender mucho y dar un buen trato a sus  clientes. Le es rentable porque se encuentra ubicada en una buena zona y es la única persona que vende estos tipos de productos por donde vive, lo que quiere decir que le va muy bien. Este es su 3er préstamo con MFP, y ha demostrado ser responsable con sus pagos. Con el dinero que solicita quiere mandar a ampliar el espacio que usa para su negocio y comprar más productos para surtir mejor su bodega.
texts.en:
Rosana is 41 with one daughter and a baby on the way. She lives with her partner, who is very helpful to her, particularly in her business. She earns her living selling groceries and household staples from her home. What she likes about her work is getting a lot of sales, and treating her customers well. The business is profitable because it is located in a good area, and Rosana is the only one selling these types of products in her vicinity, so she feels things are going well for her. This will be her third loan with MFP, and she has already proven herself responsible with respect to the payments. She will use the money to expand the space for her buiness and to stock her store with more products.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expansion of space for her grocery store

loans.name: Ami

texts.en:
Ami D. is 38 years old and a married mother of three children. Two of her children go to primary school. One of her children is still too young to attend, but will start next year. Ami lives in the village of Wome, a small town approximately 130 kilometers from Lomé, the Togolese capital.

To provide for her family, Ami sells liters of gas to taxi and taxi-moto drivers. She buys large quantities of gas, which is stored in the large black cistern in this photo. She distributes it in one-liter bottles with a funnel, pictured in front of the cistern. With this loan from Kiva, Ami hopes to refill the cistern so she can continue selling gas to her customers. Ami appreciates this opportunity from Kiva to improve her family’s quality of life and the ability to send her youngest child to school next year.

loans.use: Buy large quantities of gas to sell

loans.name: David

texts.fr: Né vers 1975 dans l’arrondissement de KESSOUNOU de la commune de DANGBO, monsieur   D. Y. David est marié et père de 2 enfants dont 0 scolarisé. Il est un cultivateur dans le village de GLAHOUNSA de la vallée de l’Ouémé et est membre du groupement  GH MISSIMAHOU DE GLAHOUNSA. Les habitants de ce village font les travaux champêtres à la décrue du fleuve ouémé. Leurs terres sont riches et les offrent un bon rendement.  Leurs spéculations principales sont la culture du maïs, du piment, des légumes, du gombo, de la tomate et du manioc. texts.en:
Mr. David D. Y. was born around 1975 in the KESSOUNOU district of DANGBO village. He is married and the father of two children, none of them attend school. He is a farmer in GLAHOUNSA village in the Ouémé valley and is a member of the HOUEDOME group GH MISSIMAHOU DE GLAHOUNSA. The inhabitants of this village work the land after the fall of the level of the Ouémé river. Their land is rich and offers a high yield. Their main activity is growing corn, peppers, vegetables, okra, tomatoes and manioc. The problem for these riverside residents is that, during the flood period, they no longer have anything to do and spend all the income generated from the sale of their harvested produce. When the river level drops they do not have any money left to pay for the workforce essential for sowing the available land. The local practice of selling cheaply the harvest does not provide them with financial security and further bankrupts them. This practice involves selling the future harvest at a rock-bottom price to an affluent person in order to have the required money to continue farming. Tired of this practice, they are requesting a loan of 140 000 FCFA (USD 275) to farm about 1.5 hectares of the aforementioned land.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Farming of 1.5 hectares of corn and peppers

loans.name: Abel

texts.fr: Né vers 1978 dans l’arrondissement de KESSOUNOU de la commune de DANGBO, monsieur   A. Abel est marié et père de 4 enfants dont 1 scolarisé. Il est un cultivateur dans le village de GLAHOUNSA de la vallée de l’Ouémé et est membre du groupement  GH MISSIMAHOU DE GLAHOUNSA. Les habitants de ce village font les travaux champêtres à la décrue du fleuve ouémé. Leurs terres sont riches et les offrent un bon rendement.  Leurs spéculations principales sont la culture du maïs, du piment, des légumes, du gombo, de la tomate et du manioc. Le problème de ces habitants riverains du fleuve est que, en période de crue, ils n’ont plus d’activité et dépensent tout le revenu issu de la campagne écoulée à la consommation. A la décrue ils n’ont plus d’argent pour payer la main d’œuvre indispensable pour emblaver la superficie à eux disponible.  La pratique dans le milieu qui consiste au bradage des récoltes ne les sécurise pas et les runes d’avantage. Cette pratique est la vente à un prix dérisoire de la récolte future a un nantis pour disposer de la somme nécessaire aux travaux champêtres. Fatigués de cette pratique il a sollicité un prêt de 140 000 FCFA pour l’exploitation d’environ 1,5hectares des spéculations susse indiquées.
texts.en:
Mr. Abel A. was born around 1978 in the KESSOUNOU district of DANGBO village. He is married and the father of four children, one of whom attend school. He is a farmer in GLAHOUNSA village in the Ouémé valley and is a member of the HOUEDOME group GH MISSIMAHOU DE GLAHOUNSA. The inhabitants of this village work the land after the fall of the level of the Ouémé river. Their land is rich and offers a high yield. Their main activity is growing corn, peppers, vegetables, okra, tomatoes and manioc. The problem for these riverside residents is that, during the flood period, they no longer have anything to do and spend all the income generated from the sale of their harvested produce. When the river level drops they do not have any money left to pay for the workforce essential for sowing the available land. The local practice of selling cheaply the harvest does not provide them with financial security and further bankrupts them. This practice involves selling the future harvest at a rock-bottom price to an affluent person in order to have the required money to continue farming. Tired of this practice, they are requesting a loan of 140 000 FCFA (USD 275) to farm about 1.5 hectares of the aforementioned land.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Exploitation 1,5hectares  du maïs, du piment

loans.name: Sandra

texts.es: Sandra tiene 29 años de edad, es madre de 2 niños que estudian, vive junto a su conviviente quien siempre está de acuerdo con sus objetivos. Ella se dedica a la venta de golosinas (galletas, caramelos, chicles, entre otras variedades), en las afueras de su domicilio, esto lo viene realizando desde hace un año, lo que le gusta de su trabajo es conocer a mucha gente y dar una buena atención a sus consumidores. Le es rentable porque su negocio se encuentra ubicado en un buen lugar que es muy transitable y concurrido, le va bien. Este es su 2do préstamo con MFP, y ha demostrado ser responsable con sus pagos. Con el dinero solicitado mandará a construir una ramada (espacio cubierto de un techo de ramas) para poder vender sus golosinas tranquilamente protegiéndose de la lluvia.
texts.en:
Sandra is a 29-year-old mother of two two school-age children. She lives with her common-law husband, who always supports her goals. She makes a living selling snacks (cookies, caramels, gum, etc.) outside of her home. She has been doing this for a year, and what she enjoys about her work is meeting many people and giving them good service. The business is profitable because it's in a good location that's often busy and gets a lot of traffic, so things have been going well. This is her second loan, and she has showed herself to be responsible with her payments. With the money she is requesting she will build a shelter to cover her so she can be at ease selling her snacks and protect herself from the rain.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build a shelter to cover and protect her business

loans.name: Teodocia

texts.es: Teodocia tiene 28 años de edad, es madre soltera, vive con sus 3 hijos que son estudiantes. Ella se dedica a la venta de abarrotes y productos de primera necesidad desde hace un año atrás, lo que le gusta de su trabajo es conocer mucha gente y dar un trato amable al momento de vender. Le es rentable porque gracias a este negocio y su carisma al atender cuenta con una gran clientela. Lo más difícil para ella es no contar con un local adecuado para la venta de sus productos. Es su primer préstamo con MFP, por lo que se compromete a ser puntual en sus cuotas. Teodocia tiene el propósito de ampliar y construir un kiosco para su negocio, además de comprar  más productos para surtir su bodega.
texts.en:
Teodocia is a 28-year-old single mother of three school-age children. She makes a living selling groceries and primary-need items, which she has been doing for a year. What she enjoys about her work is meeting many people and providing them with a friendly shopping experience. It is profitable because thanks to her business and charisma she has established a large clientele. The most difficult thing for her is she doesn't not have an adequate site to sell her products. This is her first loan, and she promises to be punctual with her payments. Teodocia's goal is to expand her business by building a kiosk and purchasing more products to stock her store.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build a kiosk and purchase products for her business

loans.name: Victor

texts.es: Victor vive con su conviviente y sus dos pequeños hijos que están estudiando. Se dedica al transporte de pasajeros desde hace 9 años, y gracias a su buena administración del dinero ahora es propietario de dos motocarros, negocio que le ayuda a fortalecer un poco más la economía de su hogar, lo que le gusta de su trabajo es el trato directo que tiene con sus pasajeros. Además sus motos solo las manejan sus familiares (sus hermanos) y las mantienen bien cuidadas, razón por la cual le va muy bien. Es su primer préstamo con MFP, por lo que se compromete a ser puntual en sus cuotas. Con el dinero solicitado quiere comprar repuestos para mandar a reparar algunas fallas mecánicas de sus motos.
texts.en:
Victor lives with his common-law wife and their two small children who are in school. He has made a living in passenger transportation for the past nine years and thanks to his administration abilities he is now the owner of two motocabs, which has help strengthen his household's finances a bit. What he enjoys about his work is the direct interaction he has with his passengers. Furthermore, the motocab drivers are his brothers and they take good care of them, another reason the business has gone so well. This is his first loan, and he promises to be punctual with his payments. With the money he's requesting, he wants to purchase parts to make some repairs on his motocabs.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase parts for his motocabs

loans.name: Virgilia

texts.es: Virgilia tiene 40 años de edad y solo vive con su conviviente, ya que sus hijos son mayores, independientes y de familia. Su actividad del día a día es la venta de abarrotes y productos de primera necesidad, labor que viene realizando desde hace un año atrás. Lo que le gusta de su trabajo es estar en contacto directo con sus clientes y desde luego darles una buena atención, para que regresen en otra oportunidad. Le es rentable porque cuenta con una clientela que le es fiel desde el primer momento en que abrió este negocio, por lo que no muestra dificultad alguna. Es su primer préstamo con MFP, por lo que se compromete a ser puntual en sus cuotas. Con el dinero que solicita mandará a ampliar su negocio, además de comprar más productos para surtirlo mejor.
texts.en:
Virgilia is 40 years old and lives alone with her common-law husband since their children are grown-up, independent and have their own families. Her day-to-day activity is selling grocery and primary-need products, which she has been doing for the past year. What she enjoys about her work is being in direct contact with her customers and providing them with quality service so they will repeat their business. It is profitable because she has established a faithful clientele from the first moment she opened her business, so she has encountered many difficulties. This is her first loan, and she promises to be punctual with her payments. With the money she is requesting she will expand her business by purchase more products to keep it better stocked.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase more products for her store

loans.name: Waldermar

texts.es: Waldemar tiene 26 años de edad, es soltero, vive junto a sus padres que lo apoyan mucho. Levantarse muy temprano a lavar motos y motocarros es la labor diaria de este joven, brindando servicios de lavado desde hace tres años en un pequeño lavadero implementado en las afueras de su casa. Lo que le gusta de su trabajo es conocer a muchas  personas, además le es muy rentable porque los conductores con sus vehículos concurren diario a su lavadero. Esto le da muchos ánimos de continuar creciendo en su negocio. Este es su 3er préstamo con MFP, y ha demostrado ser responsable con sus pagos. Con el dinero que solicita comprará mangueras para su lavadero, además quiere mandar a reparar algunas imperfecciones de su vivienda.
texts.en:
Waldemar is 26 years old, single and lives with his parents, who give him a lot of support. He gets up very early in the morning to wash vehicles, a job this young man has been doing for the past three years in a small car wash he set up outside of his home. What he enjoys about his work is meeting a lot of people, and the business is very profitable because drivers bring their vehicles everyday to his car wash. This gives him a lot of encouragement to keep growing his business. This is his third loan request, and he has shown himself to be responsible with his payments. With the money he is requesting, Waldemar plans to purchase hoses for his car wash, as well as make some repairs to his home.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase hoses for his car wash and make repairs to his home

loans.name: David

texts.fr: Né vers 1975 dans l’arrondissement de KESSOUNOU de la commune de DANGBO, monsieur   D. Y. David est marié et père de 2 enfants dont 0 scolarisé. Il est un cultivateur dans le village de GLAHOUNSA de la vallée de l’Ouémé et est membre du groupement  GH MISSIMAHOU DE GLAHOUNSA. Les habitants de ce village font les travaux champêtres à la décrue du fleuve ouémé. Leurs terres sont riches et les offrent un bon rendement.  Leurs spéculations principales sont la culture du maïs, du piment, des légumes, du gombo, de la tomate et du manioc. Le problème de ces habitants riverains du fleuve est que, en période de crue, ils n’ont plus d’activité et dépensent tout le revenu issu de la campagne écoulée à la consommation. A la décrue ils n’ont plus d’argent pour payer la main d’œuvre indispensable pour emblaver la superficie à eux disponible.  La pratique dans le milieu qui consiste au bradage des récoltes ne les sécurise pas et les runes d’avantage. Cette pratique est la vente à un prix dérisoire de la récolte future a un nantis pour disposer de la somme nécessaire aux travaux champêtres. Fatigués de cette pratique il a sollicité un prêt de 140 000 FCFA pour l’exploitation d’environ 1,5hectares des spéculations susse indiquées.
texts.en:
Born around 1975 in the district of Kessounou in the town of Dangbo, Mr. David D. Y. is married and the father of two children who are not enrolled in school. He is a farmer in the village of Glahounsa in the valley of the Ouémé and is a member of the GH Missimahou Group of Glahounsa.

The inhabitants of this village work their fields after the waters of the river Ouémé have receded. Their fields are rich and give them a good harvest. Their main crops are maize (corn), hot peppers, vegetables, okra, tomatoes, and manioc. The problem of these people who dwell along the river is that, when the river floods, they have no work and spend on food all the money they earned farming.

When the waters recede, they have no money left to pay workers who are indispensable to help them cultivate the area available to them. At this point many sell the future rights to their harvest which does not make them any more secure, but only makes things worse. They sell the rights to their future harvest to a wealthier person for a laughable sum so that they have enough money to be able to work their fields.

Weary of this system, David Da Y. is requesting a loan of 140,000 F CFA so as to farm about 1.5 hectares without resorting to "futures" speculation.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: farming 1.5 hectares in corn and hot peppers

loans.name: Epifania Francisca

texts.en:
Francisca, a member of the Manantial (“Spring”) Village Bank, is 50 years old and married with six children, all of whom are now in college. In her business, Francisca travels to mountain towns in order to sell bread and fruit and to purchase meat and cheese to sell in Ayacucho and Lima. She also raises pigs and hens for sale.

Francisca is requesting a loan of $300, half to be used to buy two young rams to be raised for later mutton sale and the other half to purchase apples, oranges and bananas to sell in mountain towns.

Francisca’s goal is to continue to advance in life so that her children will have a better future.

loans.use: To buy rams and fruit.

loans.name: Yawo

texts.en:
Yawo N. is a single young man of 19 with a strong entrepreneurial spirit. He started his business 2 years ago and has been very successful selling shirts in the central market of Wome. Wome is a small village in Togo located approximately 130 miles from the capital.

Yawo has asked for this loan from FECECAV to expand his business by diversifying his inventory. Yawo hopes to sell t-shirts, shirts with collars, and also begin offering other small products such as batteries and prepaid cellphone cards. He believes this diversified inventory will differentiate his business from other vendors in the market. With the increased revenue he will earn from expanding his business, Yawo hopes to begin saving money to start a family.

loans.use: Expand business by diversifying inventory

loans.name: Abel

texts.fr: Né vers 1978 dans l’arrondissement de KESSOUNOU de la commune de DANGBO, monsieur   A. Abel est marié et père de 4 enfants dont 1 scolarisé. Fatigués de cette pratique il a sollicité un prêt de 140 000 FCFA pour l’exploitation d’environ 1,5hectares des spéculations susse indiquées.
texts.en:
Born around 1978 in the district of Kessounou in the town of Dangbo, Mr. Abel A. is married and the father of four children one of whom is enrolled in school. He is a farmer in the village of Glahounsa in the valley of the Ouémé River and is a member of the GH Missimahou Group of Glahounsa.

The inhabitants of this village work their fields after the waters of the river Ouémé have receded. Their land is rich and gives them a good harvest. Their main crops are maize (corn), hot peppers, vegetables, okra, tomatoes, and manioc. The problem of these people who dwell along the river is that, when the river floods, they have no work and spend on food all the money they earned farming.

When the waters recede, they have no money left to pay workers who are indispensable to help them cultivate the area available to them. At this point many sell the future rights to their harvest which does not make them any more secure, but only makes things worse. They sell the rights to their future harvest to a wealthier person for a laughable sum so that they have enough money to be able to work their fields.

Weary of this system, Abel A. is requesting a loan of 140,000 F CFA so as to farm about 1.5 hectares, growing the above-mentioned crops.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: farming 1.5 hectares, raising corn (maize) and hot peppers

loans.name: Esta K.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 25-year-old Esta M. from Kyela. She is married with one child. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two dependents because they are orphans. Esta has been running a crops-selling business since 2006. Client’s business is buying crops from farmers and bringing them to town where she can sell them at a higher price.

She works at the business for 9 to 12 hours per day, 7 days per week. Esta currently earns about 100 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 325 USD in order to purchase more cacao and rice in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity of cacao and rice that she buys in bulk. Esta thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit through micro-leasing in Tanzania. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women and uses the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more cacao and rice in bulk

loans.name: Flor De Amapola Group

texts.en:
The Flor D. Amapola ("Poppy Flower") Village Bank is located in the town of Chilcapite, just east of Acobamba, the provincial capital. The village is a hilly, mostly agricultural community located about 3,300 meters above sea level. Most group members raise livestock or crops since there is little commercial activity in the area. Maxima and Isidora are two members of the Flor D. Amapola group:

Maxima is married with five children in their late 20s and early-to-mid-30s. For the past 30 years, Maxima has been buying and selling fish and fruit in local markets, sometimes preparing the fish by frying them and other times selling them uncooked. The Juntos Program was recently launched in Maxima’s area to give low-income women in rural areas $30 per month. Seeing a business opportunity, she started selling her wares outsiD. the program office on payment days.

Maxima plans to use her share of the loan to buy more fish and produce to sell and to start traveling to more regional markets. Her goal is to open a wholesale store so that she doesn’t have to travel anymore, and she is now planning to use her FINCA savings to buy a stand in the Lima market.

Isidora, married with six children between the ages of 10 and 25, buys young chickens which she fattens up to sell. Isidora has been working with FINCA for six months and says that in that time her business and her family have improved and her income has grown a bit. She is planning to use her share of the loan to buy more chickens to sell.

Isidora’s goal for the future is to expand her business by buying more chickens as well as other animals such as guinea pigs and pigs.

loans.use: To buy produce, chickens and other animals.

loans.name: Gwantwa S.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 28-year-old Gwantwa M. from Kyela. She is married with one child. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependent because the child's parents can not take care of her.

Gwantwa has been running a genge business since 2005. The Swahili word for this type of outside shop, or stall, is genge. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chili, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people usually send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal and don’t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

Gwantwa works at the business for one to four hours per day, six days per week. Gwantwa currently earns about 100 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 700 USD in order to purchase rice, soap, cooking oil, water and chewing gum in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and range of the stock. Gwantwa thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit through micro-leasing in Tanzania. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women and uses the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase rice, soap, cooking oil, water and chewing gum in bulk

loans.name: Koletha J.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 28-year-old Koletha M. from Kyela. She is married with two children, ages 9 and 10. Koletha has been running a butcher shop since 1997. She works at the business for 9 to 12 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by her husband. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to purchase more cows to butcher. In the future, she plans to establish another business. Koletha thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit through micro-leasing in Tanzania. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women and uses the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more cows for her butcher shop

loans.name: Bahati A.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Bahati K. from Kyela. She is married with four children, ages 3 to 15. Bahati has been running a fish and crops business since 2006. She buys fish from fisherman at the lake and sells them in town; she also buys crops from farmers sells them.

She works at the business for 9 to 12 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by her husband. Bahati currently earns about 100 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 550 USD in order to purchase more fish, rice and red palm seeds in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and range of the stock. Bahati thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit through micro-leasing in Tanzania. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women and uses the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more fish, rice and red palm seeds in bulk

loans.name: Hatun Tarpuy Group

texts.en:
The Hatun Tarpuy ("Big Planting") Village Bank is located in the Yaruca community, in Huamanga Province of Ayacucho District in central Peru. The Yaruca community is 3,200 meters above sea level and has a frigid climate, so the only local crops are potatoes. It is located on the left bank of the Vinchos River, and has a school for young children as well as an elementary school. Most of the village raises livestock, while some farm. Commerce is restricted to markets, where animals are bought and sold.

Benedicta and Marcelina are two members of the Hatun Tarpuy Village Bank:

Benedicta is married with four children who are 10, 8, 5 and 3 years old. Benedicta used to sell coca leaves to local farmers and travel to Nazca to sell coca and dried cactus plants, which she sold to be turned into dye. Today, she sells prepared meals in the marketplace and, thanks to loans from FINCA Peru, has been able to buy more utensils and serve more meals. She used to have to rush her clients to that they would finish eating and return their dishes, but today they can eat at a relaxed pace.

Benedicta plans to use her Kiva loan to buy bread, cheese and clothing to sell in the market. She dreams that her children will someday graduate with professional degrees, so as a start she wants to take them to the city of Ayacucho to get an education. She is saving for their sake and to be able to deal with any difficulties that might arise along the way.

Marcelina is married and has eight children ranging in age from 23 to 4 years old. She launched her business six years ago selling meals in local markets, and today she buys chickens, cheeses and cows to sell in Ayacucho and also owns a dry goods store. She says that her business used to be small and it was very difficult to work with so many children, but things have improved since then.

She plans to use her loan to buy more hens to take to Ayacucho and more merchandise to sell in her store. Her goals for the future are for her children to grow up to be working professionals and for her business to grow more. She is saving up to pay for her children’s schooling.

loans.use: To buy bread, cheese, clothing, and hens

loans.name: Salome J.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 26-year-old Salome M. from Kyela. She is single but has two children ages 3 and 6. Salome has been running a vitenge (a sarong-like garment for women) and crops business since 2006. She purchases vitenge and cacao in wholesale and sells them.

She works at the business for 9 to 12 hours per day, 7 days per week. Salome currently earns about 100 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 325 USD in order to purchase more vitenge and cocoa in bulk. In the future, she plans to open another business. Salome thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit through micro-leasing in Tanzania. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women and uses the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more vitenge and cocoa in bulk

loans.name: Fidel

texts.fr: Né vers 1973 dans l’arrondissement de KESSOUNOU de la commune de DANGBO, monsieur    H. Fidel est marié et père de 3 enfants dont 1 scolarisé. Il est un cultivateur dans le village de GLAHOUNSA de la vallée de l’Ouémé et est membre du groupement  GH MISSIMAHOU DE GLAHOUNSA. Fatigués de cette pratique il a sollicité un prêt de 100 000 FCFA pour l’exploitation d’environ 1hectares des spéculations susse indiquées.
texts.en:
Born around 1973 in the district of Kessounou in the town of Dangbo, Mr. Fidel H. is married and the father of three children one of whom is enrolled in school. He is a farmer in the village of Glahounsa in the valley of the Ouémé River and is a member of the GH Missimahou Group of Glahounsa.

The inhabitants of this village work their fields after the waters of the river Ouémé have receded. Their land is rich and gives them a good harvest. Their main crops are maize (corn), hot peppers, vegetables, okra, tomatoes, and manioc. The problem for these people who dwell along the river is that, when the river floods, they have no work and spend on food all the money they earned farming last season.

When the waters recede, they have no money left to pay workers who are indispensable to help them cultivate the area available to them. At this point many sell the future rights to their harvest which does not make them any more secure, but only makes things worse. They sell the rights to their future harvest to a wealthier person for a laughable sum so that they have enough money to be able to work their fields. Weary of this system, Fidel H. is requesting a loan of 100,000 F CFA so as to farm about 1 hectare, growing the above-mentioned crops.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: farming 1 hectare in corn and hot peppers

loans.name: Lidia S.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings) from Tanzania! This is 32-year-old Lidia A. from Kyela. She is married with four children between the ages of one and 12. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependent whose parents can not take care of her.

Lidia has been running a crops business since 2006. Her business is to purchase crops wholesale and sell them to people in the area. She works at the business for 5 to 8 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by her husband. Jeni currently earns 300 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 700 USD in order to purchase more red palm seeds in bulk. In the future, she plans to open another business. Lidia thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit through micro-leasing in Tanzania. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women and uses the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more red palm seeds in bulk

loans.name: Jeni M.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings) from Tanzania! This is 22-year-old Jeni M. M. from Kyela. She is married with one two-year-old child. Jeni has been running a tailoring business since 2004. She works at the business for 5 to 8 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by her husband. Jeni currently earns about 275 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 700 USD in order to purchase wool and other materials used for making clothes. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and range materials in bulk. Jeni thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit through micro-leasing in Tanzania. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women and uses the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase wool and other materials used for making clothes

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To invest in clothing and footwear for a small business.

loans.name: Grace J.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings) from Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Grace M. from Kyela. She is married with four children between the ages of five and 11. Grace has been running a khanga business since 2004. She buys khanga (Tanzanian traditional dress) on a wholesale basis and sells them in her shop.

Grace works at the business for 9 to 12 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by her husband. She is requesting a loan of 625 USD in order to purchase more khanga in bulk. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Grace thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit through micro-leasing in Tanzania. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women and uses the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.name: Karister A.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings) from Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Karister M. from Kyela. She is married with two children, age three and eight. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependent whose parents can not take care of her. Karister has been running a crops business since 2005: she buys cocoa, rice, beans and groundnuts from farmers and sell thems in the market at a higher price.

Karister works at the business for 13 to 16 hours per day, 6 days per week. Karister currently earns about 320 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to purchase more rice, cocoa and groundnuts in bulk. In the future, she plans to expand her business by increasing the quantity of items in bulk. Karister thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit through micro-leasing in Tanzania. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women and uses the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more rice, cocoa and groundnuts in bulk

loans.name: Artemia

texts.es: Artemia tiene 56 años D. edad, es casada, tiene 8 hijos D. los cuales 4 están con ella apoyándola en las labores agrícolas a su esposo. Cuando recién se casó trabajaba igual que su esposo labrando la tierra, pasando algunos años enfermó, desD. entonces se dedica a preparar el almuerzo D. su esposo y sus peones. Y los días D. feria en su distrito, y da riendas suelta a su arte culinario, preparando y vendiendo comida, le es muy rentable, ya que prepara un aproximado D. 30 platos D. dos a tres tipos. Está contenta por ser útil y apoyar a su esposo, la única dificultad es que no pueD. cargar mucho peso, y siempre tiene que pedir ayuda a sus hijos o vecinos. Es el noveno préstamo D. Artemia, y no tiene dificultades en sus pagos, además le tiene mucha gratitud a Microfinanzas Prisma por el apoyo que le dan. En esta oportunidad, una parte del dinero es para la compra D. víveres para el menú, y otra para la compra D. fertilizantes para la chacra.
texts.en:
Artemia is 56 years old, married, and has 8 children, 4 of which are with her, helping her in the agricultural work of her husband. When she was first married, she worked as much as her husband, working the land. After a few years passed, she got sick. Ever since then, she works preparing lunch for her husband and his laborers. And on market days in her district, she gives free rein to her culinary arts, preparing and selling food, which is very profitable since she prepares approximately 30 plates of two or three kinds. She is happy to be useful and support her husband. The only difficulty is that she cannot carry a lot of weight and always has to ask for help from her children or neighbors. This is Artemia's ninth loan and she does not have difficulty with her payments. Additionally, she is very grateful to Microfinanzas Prisma for the support that they give her. With this opportunity, part of the money is to purchase provisions for the menu and the other part to buy fertilizer for the small farm.

Translated from Spanish by Megan Tatman Montgomery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase provisions for the preparation of her food

loans.name: Cesar
