Her brother hopes to borrow 4,028,000 VND (239 USD) to buy ducks and chickens to raise. Each day, she goes to the market to trade in tea buds. Sometimes her husband goes to find extra work, which brings the income of the entire family to about 3,000,000 VND (178 USD) per month. Mrs. T. has the trust of everyone and was elected the leader of the group comprised of: Ngô Thị Lan, born 1964, hopes to borrow 4,028,000 VND (239 USD) to buy candy and snacks to sell from her home. Her income is about 70,000 VND (4 USD) per day. Vương Thị Vân, born 1966, hopes to borrow 4,028,000 VND (239 USD) to invest in raising pigs. Nguyễn Thị Vân, born 1969, hopes to borrow 4,028,000 VND (239 USD) to invest in raising pigs. She and her husband have a steady income from wages of about 3,000,000 VND (178 USD) per month. Vương Thị Nụ, born 1958, hopes to borrow 4,028,000 VND (239 USD) to invest in raising pigs. The average monthly income of her family is about 3,500,000 VND (208 USD). Nguyễn Thị Minh, born 1947, hopes to borrow 4,028,000 VND (239 USD) to invest in raising pigs. The average monthly income of her family is about 2,000,000 VND (119 USD). Vương Thị Tỵ, born 1965, hopes to borrow 4,028,000 VND (239 USD) to invest in a breakfast stand selling bún (rice noodles), phở (noodle soup), cháo (rice porridge), etc. The average monthly income of her family is about 3,500,000 VND (208 USD).

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising pigs, candy and breakfast sales

loans.name: Khorn

texts.en:
Mr. Khorn S., 59, and his wife, Mrs. Meo Say, 49, live along National Road No. Six, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1981 and have seven children; two sons and five daughters. One of their sons is deceased. The eldest daughter assists her parents in farming. The second daughter is a garment factory worker who wants to open her own business selling sugarcane juice and gasoline in front of the house. The other children attend school.
 
Khorn and his wife have been have been farming since 1992. They grow cabbage and many types of spinach on their farm near the village. They sell the produce to a middleman, who sells it in Phnom Penh.

Khorn is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase a sugarcane juice machine and to buy gasoline cans for his daughter to sell sugarcane juice and gasoline.

loans.use: To purchase a sugarcane juice machine and gasoline cans for his daughter's business.

loans.name: Ninfa

texts.en:
Ninfa Q. H. is a member of the Confianza (“Trust”) Village Bank. Ninfa is 48 years old and married with six children, of whom three live with her. Ninfa travels to regional markets three times per week to sell fruits, vegetables and fish. At the markets, she buys animals and cheese; she slaughters the animals herself and sells the meat and cheese from house to house. Ninfa also runs a store from her home, where she sells dry goods, vegetables and meat.  Ninfa needs a loan of $275 to buy sugar and rice.  Ninfa dreams of fixing her home, of opening a large restaurant to sell meals, and of saving enough to provide for her children.
Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow

loans.use: To buy sugar and rice

loans.name: Phem

texts.en:
Mrs. Phem V., 30, and her husband, Mr. Sarorn Lorn, 34, live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1995 and have five children; one son and four daughters. Three of the children attend school. 

Phem has been farming for 10 years. She grows tomatoes, spinach, and other crops on her farm, and rents some plots of land from neighboring villagers to grow crops. She sells her products to a middleman in the village, who sells it in the Phnom Penh markets. Her husband has been a motor taxi driver and also farms with her.

Phem is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase a water pump, pipe, and to pay fees for renting farmland.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump, pipe, and to pay for renting farmland.

loans.name: Yat

texts.en:
Mrs. Yat T. is a widow with three children: two sons and one daughter. Two of them attend school and the other son is still too young. Her mother lives with her also. The family lives in a small village across the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Yat has been selling fish and raising pigs for 10 years. She buys fish from the fisherman and brings it to the village for resale in the village market. Yat is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase more pigs and fish for resale.

loans.use: To purchase pigs and fish for resale.

loans.name: Mary Rose

texts.en:
Mary Rose D., 42-year-old mother of four children from Fatima, General Santos City, never stops dreaming that her children will earn a degree in college and have a good future. Her husband, a private employee, has been helping her run their store, where they earned enough for them to address their needs. 

She sells variety of goods in her store, catering to all of her neighbors and friends as customers. She aspires to expand her business to send all of her children to school.

She is requesting a loan to purchase additional items to sell in her store.

loans.use: To purchase additional items to sell in her store

loans.name: Vanna

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanna H., 43, and her husband, Mr. Sokha Kong, 45, live on an island of the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1983 and have six sons. One of their sons is married and lives outside the family home; three sons attend school.
 
Vanna has been has been raising pigs since 1984. Her husband is a taxi driver (Tuk Tuk) in Phnom Penh and assists his wife in her pig-farming business. Now, Vanna would like a loan of $ 1000 to purchase a motorcycle for her son to drive as a taxi and to carry pig feed.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her son to drive as a taxi and to transport pig feed.

loans.name: Redina

texts.en:
Redina C. A. is a member of the Azucenas (“White Lilies”) Village Bank. Redina is 32 years old and lives with her common-law husband and their two children. She and her husband sell shoes in the April 12th Market in the city of Ayacucho. They own two market stands, one of which they own, while the other is rented. They work every day of the week, and buy the shoes in Lima. Her husband also travels around to different regional fairs.  Redina needs a loan of $650 to buy sneakers and children’s shoes.  Redina’s dreams are to educate her children, to buy a car to transport her products, and to improve her home. 
Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow.

loans.use: To buy sneakers and children's shoes

loans.name: Penh

texts.en: Mr. Penh H., 66, resides in the Kompong Cham Province. He is a vegetable farmer who grows morning glories and specializes in cabbage crops. Penh is able to sell his cabbages 3 months after planting and he has been selling this crop for about seven years. He is married to Mrs. Sim Mao, 60, works with her husband in the fields and together they are the parents of three children. Penh is applying for a loan to buy a pumping machine, gasoline, and insecticides to use on his farm. (Penh's wife is shown in the picture because Penh was not available)

loans.use: To buy a pumping machine, gasoline, and insecticides for the farm.

loans.name: Angelica

texts.en: Angelica Y. E. is a member of the Confianza (“Trust”) Village Bank. She is a 28-year-old single mother with one child. Angelica sells “emoliente,” a hot drink with curative properties. She works every morning and every night selling her emoliente on the street outside of a local inter-provincial transport company. She also has a small stand at the Alipio Ponce Academy, where she sells sweets.  Angelica needs a loan of $275 to buy sweets and to fix her cart.  Angelica dreams of owning her own home, of expanding her business, and of providing her son with a good education.   Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow.

loans.use: To buy sweets for sale and to fix vending cart

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn P., 62-year-old mother of two from Calumpang, General Santos City, is a dressmaker. Her husband helps her with sewing to finish orders quickly. “I dream of giving my children the best education that I didn’t have", she said. “By sending all of them to school, I am confident that my children will have a good future after school”, she added.

She is requesting a loan to purchase materials for making dresses. She believes that she needs to invest more in fabric to attract more customers and to augment her income.

loans.use: To purchase materials for making dresses

loans.name: Akif

texts.en:
Akif Q. is 50 years old and he is married with four children. Akif is a market vendor. He sells clothing for women and children in the local market of Sabirabad city. Over the last nine years of working at the market, Akif has gained enough experience to do his work successfully and has clients who always come to him.

Akif has a large and friendly family who always try to help each other. Thus, his son is also engaged in this business. Akif wishes his children get a good education, allowing them to have a better chance to succeed in the future - this is what makes his sacrifice worthwhile. Akif works as a teacher in the local school but his salary is approximately $80 USD, which is not enough to cover basic family needs.

As his children are growing up, their expenses are rising accordingly, so in order to increase his business Akif is requesting a loan of $1200 USD. He will use the loan to purchase merchandise so he can offer a wider selection to his customers and increase his income.

The well-being of Akif’s family and his business are in your hands. Akif and his family are sincerely grateful for your support.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Elshad

texts.en:
Elshad N. is a 20-year-old enthusiastic and ambitious young man who is already the owner of a small store. He finished studies in the economics faculty but after graduating, it was very difficult to find a job in the area he lives. He borrowed money from his father and purchased some cosmetics inventory.

Elshad rents a small grocery store in the center of the town, very close to the central bazaar. He has many clients because his grocery products are cheap. He has a wish to build his own store but needs a lot of money for it. He wants to borrow money and use it in his business to make more profit. He will start saving money from his profits and hopes that soon he will be able to start building his own store.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Hak

texts.en: Hak S., 44, is a rice farmer who lives in Trapeangbeng Village in the Kampong Cham Province. She has been growing rice since 1979. She is married with four children, two of whom are married. Beside growing rice, S. purchases cashews from growers and sells them to wholesalers for a profit. Hak is requesting a loan to purchase more cashews for resale.

loans.use: To purchase cashews for resale.

loans.name: Fakhraddin

texts.en:
Fakhraddin K. is 39 years old. He is married with three adorable children. Fakhraddin has always opted to make his life in his land and work hard and grow with it. That is how he decided to raise sheep and dedicated himself to farming. He has been doing this kind of work since 2003, but before he was helping his family who have an entirely agricultural background. Fakhraddin raises sheep and sells them to local restaurants and cafes, and he also has his own café.

Today he wishes to increase the number of his sheep and for this reason he would like to buy 15 sheep and fodder. He hopes to increase his income and the well-being of his home with the innumerable benefits that these special animals provide him. That’s why he is requesting a loan of 1200 USD for a term of 15 months.

Extend your solidarity to Fakhraddin so that he can move forth successfully and accomplish all his goals!

loans.use: purchase 15 sheep and fodder

loans.name: Khakim

texts.en:
Khakim M., 47, and his wife are raising four children. They are his inspiration to work hard every day and continue with his business. When Khakim lost his job, he was left without steady income. After long suffering, he decided to open a grocery store near his house.

Khakim is trying to generate income not only for his family's consumption but also to be able to create savings for the dowries of his daughters and future weddings of all of their children, but it is very hard. Today Khakim is planning to increase the range of his inventory. With this purpose in mind, he is requesting 1200 USD for a term of 15 months. Support this man of much strength and courage to keep working! Your generosity can change his family’s lives.

loans.use: purchase more inventory

loans.name: Moeung

texts.en: Mrs. Moeung S. H. , 38, is a resident of the Kompong Cham Province. She makes a living by growing different kinds of vegetables such as cabbages and morning glories. Her income is the main source of the family income. She is a widow and the  mother of one young child that she would like to provide with a high education. To earn extra income and grow her business, Moeung  is requesting a loan to order fish and vegetables to sell and any remaining money will be used to buy more seeds and repair a pumping machine.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fish, and vegetables.

loans.name: Hanieh

texts.en: Hanieh is a 48 year old single woman living in Bazourieh, Southern Lebanon, and has been working as a tailor since 2005. Hanieh first started selling textiles to her neighbors and friends. After several years, she wanted to open her own shop and shifted to tailoring. Today, Hanieh wants to borrow $1,200 to buy textiles and a sewing kit to provide a variety of products for her clientele.

loans.use: Buy textiles and a sewing kit

loans.name: Khalil

texts.en: Khalil is a 48-year-old married man with four children. Living in Baalback, Khalil has been trading used cars since 2000 in Zahleh area. Working on a very small scale, Khalil can only afford to trade one car at a time. He recently purchased a car with good selling potential; however, it needs maintenance. He is therefore requesting a loan of $1000 to buy the spare parts he needs to repair the vehicle.

loans.use: Buy spare parts to repair a car for resale

loans.name: Charito

texts.en:
Charito C., a 46-year-old mother of seven children, is selling bananas and other food items in Polomolok, South Cotabato. She never minds the labor just to earn enough for her and her children and to have food to eat. Charito thinks that with her husband's salary as a laborer, they could hardly meet all their family needs.

She is requesting a loan to purchase more bananas to sell in the market. She believes that by purchasing more bananas, she could augment her income.“I dream of sending all my children to school to become professionals someday”, she said. “ As long as I live, I’ll support them to achieve their dreams”, she added.

loans.use: To purchase more bananas to sell in the market

loans.name: Ban

texts.en:
Ban P., 40, is married and lives with three of her children and her husband in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She is a pig breeder on a plot of farm behind her house. On average, she makes around $1 a day. Her husband Sreng Sreang, 39, works growing rice with two of his children and makes $3 a day. He has been farming for about 10 years. The weather conditions have been difficult in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have created a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Sreng Sreang included.

Ban P. is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase a grinding mill. This machine will service the people in the village for extra profit.

loans.use: To purchase a grinding mill

loans.name: Khajik

texts.en: Khajik is a 43-year-old man living in Jalala in the Bekaa valley. He has owned a car accessories shop since 1988. Khajik has a new innovative product that he wants to introduce to the market. He is asking for $1,200 in order to finance the purchase of this new product.

loans.use: Purchase new products for automotive shop

loans.name: Korng

texts.en:
Korng K. T., 51, is married and resides with one of her children and her husband in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. Since 1979, she has been working as a village doctor making around $10 a day, while her husband Porn Phan, 55, works breeding pigs on a plot of land behind his house. Every month, Korng spends $60 on food, $30 on her children's education, and $30 on transportation. 

Korng K. T. would like to take out a loan of $1000 to purchase a motorbike to use commuting to work. This will reduce her daily transportation costs. (Her husband is pictured.)

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Huy

texts.en: Mrs. Huy A., age 46, is a local farmer that, since 1979, has been growing rice to earn a living for her family. She also raises pigs from a small pigpen in her home. Huy has six children; three sons are factory workers, two daughters are students, and another one is married and lives away from home. She is married to Lim Try, 68, who is also a rice farmer. Huy is requesting a loan to purchase more piglets to raise. The family lives in the Kompong Cham Province.

loans.use: To purchase more piglets to raise.

loans.name: Sem

texts.en:
Sem M., 65, is married and lives with two of her children in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She stays at home doing house work and cooking food for her family members. Her husband Teab Yet, 65, works selling ice-cream in the village to earn approximately $6 a day. He sells banana ice-cream. This couple also gets support from two of their children who work as butchers. Every month, Sem M. spends around $60 on food and $20 on transportation. 

She would like to take out a loan of $1000 to purchase more pigs for her children to expand their business. (Her husband is pictured.)

loans.use: To purchase pigs

loans.name: Pek

texts.en:
Pek K., 31, is married and lives with two young children and her husband in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She and her husband are vegetable vendors in the market, earning around $6 a day.

Pek K. would like to take out a loan of $700 to purchase a motorbike to transport their crops to market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Chong

texts.en:
Chong T., 42, is married and lives with her husband in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. Since 2006, she has been selling used clothes to earn a living and is able to make $7 a day. Her husband Kong Sron, 44, is a worker and makes $6 a day. This couple together has six children, one of who is married and lives away from home. The others are students. 

Chong T. would like to take out a loan of $1000 to increase her clothes inventory. This will allow her to get more clients. (She is pictured with her husband.)

loans.use: To add clothes to inventory

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en: Mahmoud, a 26-year-old married man, works as a butcher in his home village of Marwanieh in southern Lebanon. Mahmoud realizes that with his growing business he needs to improve the shop window. Mahmoud is requesting $1,000 to gain recognition among his village peers.

loans.use: Improve the shop window

loans.name: Mon

texts.en:
Mon H., 48, is married and lives with her twin children and her husband in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She and her husband work making rice noodles and selling them at the village market. On average, they make a combined income of about $10 a day.

Mon H. would like to take out a loan of $1000 to operate a new business selling rice. This will allow her to make additional profit to help support her family.

loans.use: To purchase rice for sale.

loans.name: Apronia B.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 32-year-old Apronia K. from Kyela, divorced with one child aged 14. Apronia has been running a crops business since 2006, buying crops from farmers and bringing them to town where she can sell them at a higher price.

Working at the business for 9-12 hours per day, six days per week and assisted by her mother, Apronia currently earns about $30 per month. She is requesting a loan of $250 in order to purchase maize, beans and rice, and in the future plans to establish another business. Apronia thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase maize, beans and rice.

loans.name: Pin

texts.en:
Pin S., 49, is a true entrepreneur who lives with three of her children and husband in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She raises pigs and cooks for the garment factory workers near her house. She receives money and cooks for them. On average, she makes $3 a day, while her husband is a farmer. He grows and sells cashew nuts and yams to earn a living, and is able to make approximately $3.50 a day. One of their children is a student, and two help their parents work. 

Pin S. would like to take out a loan of $1000. Her husband will use some of the money to purchase yams from individual growers for resale. The rest of the money will be used to purchase feed for her pigs.

loans.use: To purchase yams

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is a 29-year-old single man living in Jalala in the Bekaa valley. In 2000, Ahmad decided to open his own business as a hairdresser. Naming his barbershop Chanel, the young man caters to a wide range of clientele in the village and its neighborhoods. Today, Ahmad wishes to improve the decor of his barbershop and buy specially designed barber chairs. In order to do so, Ahmad is requesting $1,200.

loans.use: Buy specially designed barber chairs

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira P. is a 51-year-old mother of two children from Fatima, General Santos City. Her husband, a retailer of rice, has been very supportive of her in her charcoal-retail business. Together, they work hard to address all their family needs.She is a loving wife and continuously dreams of a good future for her family.

She is requesting a loan to purchase additional stocks of charcoal to sell. She started her business for additional income for her family and to support her children.

"As a mother, I always seek the best things for my kids”, she said.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Chausiku D.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 44-year-old Chausiku M. from Kyela. She is married with four children, between the ages of 10 and 28. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting 2 dependants who are orphans. Chausiku has been running a local restaurant, 'Mama Lishe', since 1996.

When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is 'restaurant' or 'café', you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all-local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.

She works at the business for 9-21 hours per day, 7 days per week. Chausiku currently earns about $170 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of $250 USD in order to purchase additional stock of maize flour, rice, beans, and cooking oil. In the future, she plans to establish another business and to employ more workers. Chausiku thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA:

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of maize flour, rice, beans, and cooking oil

loans.name: Sharifan Riasat Ali Group

texts.en:
Sharifan Baji ("baji" is an honorific meaning older sister) is a group leader of a few women in her locality. Irshad Baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her animal selling business. Asghari Baji wants a loan to buy an embroidery machine for her business. Sugran Baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Nasreen Baji wants a loan to repair her truck.  

Sharifan Baji is a 42-year-old lady who resides in the city of Lahore, Pakistan. She has been living in this city for the past 25 years. Her husband name is R. A. who is a driver by profession and drives an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). 

She has five children: four sons and one daughter. Her eldest son completed his education to the 8th grade and works in a factory. The next oldest is a driver and also drives an auto-rickshaw. The next younger son is studying in 7th grade and her youngest son is in 5th grade. Her daughter makes embroidered dresses and also does household tasks. 

Sharifan Baji is a very responsible woman and performs her duties very efficiently. She also handles her decorative embroidery business which she started 15 years back. Now she has became expert in this business. She makes embroidered dresses and sells them in big clothing shops. She charges 1,500 Pak Rupees per dress. She is saving her income for her children’s education and for her daughter’s marriage. 

She successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (Kiva's microfinance institution partner in Pakistan). Now, she is applying for a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To repair auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Ouch

texts.en:
Ouch S., 54, is a widow and lives with one child in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She sells firewood and makes $6 a day. She also receives support from her child who works in a garment factory. 

Ouch S. has requested a loan of $500 to purchase a motorbike for her son-in-law to operate a mototaxi.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Set

texts.en: Mr. Set S., 58, is a resident of the Kompong Cham Province. He makes a living growing rice as well as managing a small caged in area used for breeding ducks and pigs. He has specialized in this business for over 20 years. He is married to Yi Saron, 63, a rice farmer who is the mother of two daughters; both of whom are employed as garment workers in Phnom Penh City. Set has applied for this loan to enlarge his business by buying piglets and fertilizer with any remaining money being used to pay for plowing his field.

loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Chan N., 44, is married and resides with her husband in the Battambang province, Cambodia. She is a true entrepreneur who sells various kinds of fruits in a busy market to earn a living. She is able to make $3.50 profit per day, while her husband is a taxi driver. On average, he makes $3 a day. This couple together has five children, and all of them are students.

Chan N. would like to take out a loan of $1000 to add to her inventory of fruit.

loans.use: To add to her fruit inventory

loans.name: Olesya

texts.en:
Olesya is 28 years old, married, and has one small son. She sells women's underwear and bathrobes at Vasilievka market. Her working capital is 16,000 UAH.

Olesya is new to business. She only started six months ago. She was advised to start business by her sister, who sells her goods in the next booth and has more experience in business. Her sister helped her to get the loan and gives some advice as to what to buy and how to sell. 

Olesya is a hardworking and responsible person. She believes she can make her business grow. Olesya would like to get a loan of 1,500 UAH for six weeks to buy more women's underwear to sell during the Christmas season. She hopes to receive additional income and better provide for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more inventory

loans.name: Saom

texts.en: Saom R. is married and lives with five of her children in the Battambang province, Cambodia. Working a farm with her husband, she typically makes $2.50 each day. Her family is also supported by three of the children who work in the garment factories. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year, and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have created a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Saom R. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of $1000 to create new business and purchase a motorbike. She will sells vegetables in the market and use the motorbike to transport crops to the market. This is a purchase that she believes can increase her daily income.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike and sell vegetables

loans.name: Rehana Kosar Shoqat Ali Shaheen Group

texts.en:
My name is Rehana Kosar and I have resided in Lahore, Pakistan for the past 20 years. I was educated to the 8th standard and couldn’t study further due to my father's low income. I belong to a poor family but I want to fulfill my children’s wishes. I am a mother of five children: two sons and three daughters. My elder son is in 7th standard and my younger son in 5th standard. My elder daughter is in 5th standard. The next to her is in 3rd standard and the younger to her is in 2nd standard. My children want to get a good education.

My husband is a delivery man. He delivers different items (fruits and vegetables) from one place to another. He has been in this business for the past 20 years. I belong to a decorative embroidery business. I learned this art from my mother when I left school. This work helps me a lot in having an independent life. I sell my work in cloth shops and earn a profit. I save my income to pay my children’s school and tuition fees. My husband pays the all house expenses. I have successfully repaid my two loans loan which I took from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now I am applying for a loan again to repair my husband's truck so that he is able to continue his work again actively.

I am a group leader of a few more women in my locality. Fozia Baji wants a loan to buy iron to resell. Bushra Baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits for her fruit selling business. Riaz Baji wants a loan to buy milk for her milk shop. Mahnaz Baji wants a loan to buy clothes for her clothes selling business. Azra Parveen Baji wants a loan to buy ingredients (lentils, cooking oil and spices) for her food business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To repair a truck

loans.name: Doeum

texts.en:
Doeum C. is married and lives with one child and her husband in the Battambang province, Cambodia. She sells groceries from her home to earn a living and is able to make $3 profit a day. Her husband is a translator in a private company. He makes $7 each day. 

Doeum C. would like to take out a loan of $1000 to diversify her stock and to make repairs on her house.

loans.use: To diversify her stock and repair her house

loans.name: Yat

texts.en: Yat Y., 45, is a farmer that grows rice and other crops for sale. She grows soy-beans on her farmland which takes three or four months to bring to market. She has been farming since 1979 and currently earns around $2 per day. She is married with four sons, all of whom are single. Two of her children are employed as garment workers in Phnom Penh City and they often help to support the family.  Lacking farmland to grow her soy-bean crop, Yat needs to rent farmland from other people. She is now requesting a loan to rent farmland for growing soy-beans to sell.

loans.use: To rent farmland for growing soy-beans

loans.name: Mok

texts.en: Mok K., 36, is married and lives with her three children in the Kampong Cham province. She works in a grocery store, making around $3.30 each day, while her husband is a horse-cart driver. Her husband makes about $10 each day. Food prices have soared in the past year as inflation has gotten out of control in Cambodia. Unfavorable climate conditions have also been a factor in making the price of rice very high. Mok K. is asking for a loan of $750 to purchase a good horse for her husband. She is confident that this will be a good business venture and sees it as a tool to increase her income and raise her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase a horse

loans.name: Seema Manzoor Hussain Group

texts.en:
Seema baji is 46 years old and has lived in Lahore, Pakistan for her entire life. Her husband is named M. H. and he works in a factory. She is the mother of five children: four sons and one daughter. Her first two sons work in a factory. The other two are enrolled in a local school. Her daughter is 20 years old and stays at home to help with household work. Seema baji runs a grocery store which she opened at her house. She started this business because her husband’s income is insufficient to meet household expenses and the cost of her children’s education. She has been in this line of work for three years, and has repaid a previous loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a new loan to buy groceries for her shop. 

She leads a group with several other members who live nearby. Rani baji and Musarat baji each want a loan to repair their auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Sanobar baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw. Rashidan baji wants a loan to buy a flour polisher to resell. Sabiha naz baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her store. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery shop and other items

loans.name: Naseem Akhtar Munir Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Naseem akhtar baji is 54 years old and lives in Lahore, Pakistan. She owes a two-room brick house that she has lived in for the past 20 years. Her husband is M. A., and he makes a living as a professional driver. Naseem baji has four children: three sons and one daughter. Her elder son works in a factory; the next-youngest is a delivery man who carries different items from one place to another. Her youngest son is in the sixth grade. Naseem baji has a business doing decorative embroidery. She makes dresses and sells cloth, with the help of her daughter. She has successfully repaid an earlier loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to repair her husband’s vehicle so that he can continue to work efficiently.  

Naseen leads a loan group with several other members. Jamila baji wants a loan to buy flour for her bread-making and selling business. Rasoolan baji wants a loan to repair her tractor. Sughran baji wants a loan to buy utensils to resell. Azmat baji wants a loan to buy supplies for her fruit-selling business. 

This is a group loan. Funds will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To repair a vehicle and buy items for several other businesses

loans.name: Khet

texts.en: Khet S., 48, is married and lives in the Kampong Cham province with her four children. She works as a farmer and is typically able to make $1.30 each day. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year, and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have created a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, as food prices have also been high. Khet's husband works as a carpenter and typically makes $1.40 every day. Two of her children are married and no longer live at home, while one is a student and another is a tailor. She has seen an opportunity to expand her children's business and wants to take out a loan to make a few purchases. She is asking for $700 to purchase cloth for her child to make clothes. She feels that this new aspect of her child’s business will allow her to increase her income and to raise the standard of living for the whole family.

loans.use: To purchase cloth

loans.name: Moung

texts.en: Moung Y., 45, is married and lives with eight of her ten children and her husband in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She sells vegetables in the market and makes $3.30 a day, while her husband is a farmer and construction worker building houses. He makes $4.50 a day. This couple also receives support from two of their children who work in garment factories. Two of their children are married and no longer live at home, three are students, and the rest help their parents work. Moung Y. would like to take out a loan of $1000 to rent a cashew nut farm and resell the nuts.

loans.use: To rent cashew nut farm

loans.name: Im

texts.en: Im S., 36, is married and lives with her four children in the Kampong Cham province. She is a farmer who makes around US $2 each day, while her husband works selling ice cream and makes $6 a day. Three of their children are students and one is too young to attend school. The agriculture industry has really suffered in Cambodia over the past year, as the climate has had unfavorable conditions and inflation has been high. Im S. is asking for a loan of US $1000 to purchase gas and resell it to the farmers who use tractors to plow land. With this purchase, the family believes that it can increase its income and raise the standard of living for the whole family. (Husband is pictured.)

loans.use: To purchase gas.

loans.name: Chhum

texts.en: Chhum S. is married and lives with her husband and young child in the Kampong Cham province of Cambodia. She is a midwife who earns $2 a day, while her husband is a village chief who also earns $2 a day.  She would like a loan of $1000 to reinvest with her sister to open a food shop at Phnom Penh. She believes that a food shop can increase their income and raise the standard of living for the whole family.

loans.use: To open a food shop.

loans.name: Rath

texts.en:
Rath N., 54, lives in Kampong Cham and has sold rice noodles since 2000. On average, she makes $2 a day. Rice noodles, called in the Cambodia language “Nom Banchok,” are one of the favorite foods among Cambodians. Rice noodles are served with mint, banana blossoms, string beans, English cucumber, mung bean sprouts, and other vegetables. Rice noodles can also be used in green and red soup. Green soup, called “Nom Banchok Samlah Khmer,” is cooked with boneless fish. Red soup, called “Nom Banchok Namya,” is cooked with pork or chicken. 

Rath N.'s husband is a farmer who makes about $1.5 a day.  She would like a loan of $500 to make two investments.  First, to purchase a water pump for her husband to irrigate his farmland; and second, open a grocery store for her children to start a business to augment the family's income. (Rath is pictured with her husband.)

loans.use: To purchase a water pump and open a grocery store.

loans.name: Pavel

texts.en:
Pavel sells various home products at the central market in Kherson city. He has been in this business for 16 years and is an experienced entrepreneur. His kiosk is located at a good place where many people pass by.

Pavel is very disciplined and hard working. He also knows how to listen to people and build good relationships. He started his business because he wanted to be financially independent from the government and other employers. He has an analytical mind and is always thinking of ways to develop his business. 

Pavel has applied for a loan to generate more income and invest in new ideas. He understands that in business one always needs to adjust and change to be successful.

loans.use: to increase the assortment of items he has to sell

loans.name: Loun

texts.en:
Loun N., 39, is married and lives with her husband and two of her four children in the Kampong Cham province of Cambodia. Since 2001, she has been selling fruit in the market to earn a living and is able to make $4 a day.  Her husband is a taxi driver, earning around $2.5 a day to help support the family members. This couple also is supported by one child who works selling fruit with her mother. 

Loun N. would like to take out a loan of $700 to breed pigs for extra profit. This will allow her family to improve their standard of living. (Her husband is pictured.)

loans.use: To breed pigs.

loans.name: Saing

texts.en: Saing C., 53, is a widow who resides with four of her children in the Kampong Cham province of Cambodia. She makes $2 a day selling porridge. She is also supported by two of her children who work in the garment factory and also collect palm juice. Saing C. would like to take out a loan of $600 to purchase wood for her children to use to boil the palm juice to refine palm sugar.

loans.use: To purchase wood to use as fuel for refining palm sugar

loans.name: Som

texts.en: Som S., 28, is married and lives with her husband and her three young children in the Kampong Cham province of Cambodia. She is a farmer who grows and raises pigs, making around US$4 each day, while her husband makes $5 a day as a construction worker who builds houses. The agriculture industry has really suffered in Cambodia over the past year, as the climate has had unfavorable conditions and inflation has been high. Som S. is asking for a loan of US$800 to purchase a mill to provide grinding services for an additional profit. With this purchase, the family believes that they can increase their income and raise the standard of living for the whole family.

loans.use: To purchase a grinding mill.

loans.name: Bi

texts.en: Bi S., 37, lives in the Kampong Cham province of Cambodia. She grows and sells bananas and earns about $4.6 of profit a day. Her husband Som Kean, 31, is a horse-cart driver who transports goods and villagers. On average, he makes about $3 a day. This couple together has four children: two are students, one works, and one is too young to attend school. Bi S. is asking for a loan of $200 to purchase a good horse for her husband. This will allow him to provide more and faster transport for his customers.

loans.use: To purchase a good horse.

loans.name: Vicky

texts.en:
Vickiy M. sells perfumes at her shop. She is requesting a loan to expand the shop. Vicky is 25 years old and single. With the extra capital from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a big shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services that are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To build a bigger perfume shop.

loans.name: Chhut's Group

texts.en:
This is a group loan that is composed of four borrowers that all reside in the Battambang Province. Mrs. Chhut T., 43, is a local tailor. She owns and runs a small shop in her home to sew both traditional clothes and modern clothes for her neighbors. She is able to earn an income of approximately of $4 per day. Chhut is married with two children, both of whom are still young and attend school. She is requesting a loan to purchase a sewing machine to help her business. Chhut is a leader of the other three borrowers:

Mrs. Ma T., 42, a widow. She is a tailor who is requesting a loan to build a restroom.

Mrs. Sun P., 55, is a local tailor. She seeks a loan to pay for repairing her sewing machine.

Mrs. Rin S., 31, makes a living by catching fish with her husband. She is requesting a loan to buy fishing tools such as nets and traps.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine

loans.name: Shahnaz Nazir Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Shahnaz baji is 43 years old and a mother of four children: three sons and one daughter. Her first two sons are mechanics and run a motor workshop. Her younger son works in a factory. Her daughter memorizes the holy book Quran-e-Pak. Shahnaz baji has a decorative embroidery business. She does this work to give her daughter a good future. She is very much attached to her daughter because her sons are settled in their own works. Shahnaz baji’s husband is a driver by profession and drives an auto-rickshaw (a local thee-wheeled motor vehicle). She is applying for a loan to buy repair tools for her sons' motor workshop.

She is a group leader of a few more women in her locality. Noor Fatima baji wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw and Sumera baji wants a loan to buy clothes for her clothes selling business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy repair tools for motor workshop

loans.name: Alexander

texts.en:
Alexander, who lives with his elderly mother, started his upholstery business five years ago after losing his job. He enjoys working with his hands and enabling people to have nice furniture, and earns an average monthly income of over $300.

Alexander is now requesting a loan to purchase materials he needs in his business. Acquiring these necessary materials quickly will help him to complete orders in a timely fashion and be paid promptly. Alexander’s goal is to develop his business further in order to have a stable personal income.

loans.use: To purchase upholstery materials.

loans.name: Akongo

texts.en:
Akongo R. sells beans at the market and is requesting a loan to construct a house. Akongo is 30 years old and married. Her husband is a soldier. She has three children, none of whom go to school. With the extra capital from her loan, she hopes to be able to construct a house.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services that are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To construct a house for her family.

loans.name: Gnem

texts.en: Gnem K., 45, is married and lives with her husband and four of her children in the Kampong Cham province of Cambodia. She grows and sells banana wholesale to the market to earn a living and she is able to make $4.5 a day.  Her husband is a motor-taxi driver who earns $1 a day. One child is a student, one is a car driver, and two help her grow bananas. She is asking for a loan of $800 to rent more land to grow bananas.

loans.use: To rent more land to grow bananas.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.fr: Né vers 1978 dans l’arrondissement de KESSOUNOU de la commune de DANGBO, monsieur A. Daniel est marié et père de 4 enfants dont 2 scolarisé. Il est un cultivateur dans le village de GLAHOUNSA de la vallée de l’Ouémé et est membre du groupement  GH MISSIMAHOU DE GLAHOUNSA. Les habitants de ce village font les travaux champêtres à la décrue du fleuve ouémé. Leurs terres sont riches et les offrent un bon rendement.  Leurs spéculations principales sont la culture du maïs, du piment, des légumes, du gombo, de la tomate et du manioc. Le problème de ces habitants riverains du fleuve est que, en période de crue, ils n’ont plus d’activité et dépensent tout le revenu issu de la campagne écoulée à la consommation. A la décrue ils n’ont plus d’argent pour payer la main d’œuvre indispensable pour emblaver la superficie à eux disponible.  La pratique dans le milieu qui consiste au bradage des récoltes ne les sécurise pas et les runes d’avantage. Cette pratique est la vente à un prix dérisoire de la récolte future a un nantis pour disposer de la somme nécessaire aux travaux champêtres. Fatigués de cette pratique il a sollicité un prêt de 100 000 FCFA pour l’exploitation d’environ 1hectares des spéculations susse indiquées.
texts.en:
Born around 1978 in the district of Kessounou in the town of Dangbo, Mr. Daniel A. is married and the father of 4 children, of whom two are attending school. He is a farmer in the village of Glahounsa in the valley of the Ouémé River and a member of the GH Missimahou Group of Glahounsa.

The inhabitants of this village work as farmers when the river level is low. Their land is rich and gives them a good harvest. Their principal crops are maize (corn), hot peppers, vegetables, okra, tomatoes, and manioc. The problem for these people who dwell along the river is that when the river is in flood, they have no more work and spend all the money they earned during the last farming season on foodstuffs. When the waters recede they have no money left to pay laborers who are indispensible to them in cultivating the land they own.

The custom of borrowing against the new harvest does not make them more secure and indeed leaves them worse off. They sell their future harvest at a laughable price to weathier persons so that they have the cash needed to do their farming. Weary of this practice, Daniel A. has requested a loan of 100,000 F CFA which will allow him to farm about 1 hectare, growing the aforementioned crops.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: farming of 1 hectare, in corn (maize) and hot peppers

loans.name: Un

texts.en: Un S., 40, is married and resides with her husband and six of their children in the Kampong Cham province of Cambodia. She and her husband are farmers who grow bananas and beans. The couple also obtained a mill, with which they provide grinding service to the people in the village for additional profit. On average, they earn a combined income of around $14 a day. Two of their children work in garment factories and three are students.  Un S. is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase a horse and a cart to help her transport bananas and beans from her home to the market.

loans.use: To purchase horse and a cart to transport farm produce.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.fr: Né vers 1978 dans l’arrondissement de KESSOUNOU de la commune de DANGBO, monsieur  A. Emmanuel est marié et père de 4 enfants dont 2 scolarisé. Il est un cultivateur dans le village de GLAHOUNSA de la vallée de l’Ouémé et est membre du groupement  GH MISSIMAHOU DE GLAHOUNSA. Les habitants de ce village font les travaux champêtres à la décrue du fleuve ouémé. Leurs terres sont riches et les offrent un bon rendement.  Leurs spéculations principales sont la culture du maïs, du piment, des légumes, du gombo, de la tomate et du manioc. Le problème de ces habitants riverains du fleuve est que, en période de crue, ils n’ont plus d’activité et dépensent tout le revenu issu de la campagne écoulée à la consommation. A la décrue ils n’ont plus d’argent pour payer la main d’œuvre indispensable pour emblaver la superficie à eux disponible.  La pratique dans le milieu qui consiste au bradage des récoltes ne les sécurise pas et les runes d’avantage. Fatigués de cette pratique il a sollicité un prêt de 100 000 FCFA pour l’exploitation d’environ 1hectares des spéculations susse indiquées.
texts.en:
Born around 1978 in the district of Kessounou in the town of Dangbo, Mr. Emmanuel A. is married and the father of 4 children, of whom two are attending school. He is a farmer in the village of Glahounsa in the valley of the Ouémé River and a member of the GH Missimahou group of Glahounsa.

The inhabitants of this village work as farmers when the river level is low. Their land is rich and gives them a good harvest. Their principal crops are maize (corn), hot peppers, vegetables, okra, tomatoes, and manioc. The problem for these people who dwell along the river is that when the river is in flood, they have no more work and spend all the money they earned during the last farming season on foodstuffs. When the waters recede, they have no money left to pay laborers who are indispensible to them in cultivating their land.

The custom of borrowing against the new harvest does not make them more secure and indeed leaves them worse off. They sell their future harvest at a laughable price to weathier persons so that they have the cash needed to do their farming. Weary of this practice, Emmanuel A. has requested a loan of 100,000 F CFA which will allow him to farm about 1 hectare, growing the aforementioned crops.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: farming one hectare, growing corn and hot peppers

loans.name: Lon

texts.en: Lon S., 48, is a wedding chef who lives with her husband (pictured) in the Kampong Cham province of Cambodia. She makes around $1.5 a day, while her husband is a construction supervisor who makes $6 a day. The couple has three children -- one is a student and two are employed as workers.  She is asking for a loan of $1200 to purchase construction tools for her husband. This will allow him access to bigger construction projects.

loans.use: To purchase construction tools.

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora L. is currently in the business of selling alcohol. Flora is 20 years old and is divorced. With the extra capital from her loan, she hopes to be able to construct a house and open up shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services that are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To construct a house and open up shop

loans.name: Khat

texts.en: Khat T., 49, is the mother of five children.  She lives with her husband in the Kampong Cham province of Cambodia. She sells rice noodles to earn a living and is able to make $3 a day. Her husband is farmer who grows rice. Four of their children are employed as garment factory workers. Khat T. would like to take out a loan of $600 to purchase a motorbike for her son to operate a motor-taxi. This service will allow her family to make an additional income.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Kalisa

texts.en:
Greetings from Kalisa G. in the Northern province of Rwanda! Kalisa, 44 years old and married with four children, has owned a butcher shop located in the Ruhengeri Market for the past 10 years. He began this business when he returned to Rwanda from Democratic Republic of Congo after the Genocide of 1994.

Kalisa is requesting a loan to increase his working capital and offer better service to his customers. This loan will be repaid in eight months

loans.use: To increase his working capital.

loans.name: Paul

texts.fr: Né vers 1956 dans l’arrondissement de KESSOUNOU de la commune de DANGBO, monsieur  H. Paul est marié et père de 8 enfants dont 6 scolarisés. Il est un cultivateur dans le village de GLAHOUNSA de la vallée de l’Ouémé et est membre du groupement   GM SENABLO DE GLAHOUNSA. Les habitants de ce village font les travaux champêtres à la décrue du fleuve ouémé. Leurs terres sont riches et les offrent un bon rendement.  Leurs spéculations principales sont la culture du maïs, du piment, des légumes, du gombo, de la tomate et du manioc qui sont des aliments de grande consommation au Bénin. Le problème de ces habitants riverains du fleuve est que, en période de crue, ils n’ont plus d’activité et dépensent tout le revenu issu de la campagne écoulée à la consommation. A la décrue ils n’ont plus d’argent pour payer la main d’œuvre indispensable pour emblaver la superficie à eux disponible.  La pratique dans le milieu qui consiste au bradage des récoltes ne les sécurise pas et les runes d’avantage. Cette pratique est la vente à un prix dérisoire de la récolte future à un nanti pour disposer de la somme nécessaire aux travaux champêtres. Fatigués de cette pratique il a sollicité un prêt de 190 000 FCFA pour l’exploitation d’environ 2hectares des spéculations susse indiquées.
texts.en:
Born around 1956 in the district of Kessounou in the town of Dangbo, Mr. Paul H. is married and the father of 8 children, of whom six are attending school. He is a farmer in the village of Glahounsa in the valley of the Ouémé River and a member of the GH Missimahou group of Glahounsa.

The inhabitants of this village work as farmers when the Ouémé River is low. Their land is rich and gives them a good harvest. Their principal crops are maize (corn), hot peppers, vegetables, okra, tomatoes, and manioc. The problem for these people who dwell along the river is that when the river is in flood, they have no more work and spend all the money they earned during the last farming season on foodstuffs. When the waters recede, they have no money left to pay laborers who are indispensible to them in sowing their land.

The custom of borrowing against the new harvest does not make them more secure and indeed leaves them worse off. They sell their future harvest at a laughable price to weathier persons so that they have the cash needed to do their farming. Weary of this practice, Paul H. has requested a loan of 190,000 F CFA which will allow him to farm about 2 hectares, growing the aforementioned crops.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: cultivating 2 hectares in corn (maize) and hot peppers

loans.name: Ruth J.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 33-year-old Ruth M. from Mbarali. Married with one child aged four, she is additionally responsible for supporting two dependents whose parents cannot take care of them. Ruth has been operating a soft drinks business and salon since 2002. 

Working at the business 9-12 hours per day, seven days per week, and currently earning about $406 a month, she is now requesting a loan of $625 to buy additional stocks of soft drinks and salon equipment. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and range of her stock. Ruth thanks you for your support!

It is said that Coca Cola® is one of the most recognized symbols or ‘words’ in the world and it’s true. Even in the most remote villages in Africa, there is usually some kind of ‘bar’ selling Coke, Fanta, and Guiness (Pepsi has made it to most African capitals but not to the sticks, but I’m sure they’re working on it!). The hot weather makes soft drinks all the more appealing - a very cheap marketing tool! This explains why selling soft drinks is such a popular venture, whether you’re the CEO of Coca Cola Ltd in the United States or a micro-entrepreneur in Tanzania! 

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy additional stocks of soft drinks and salon equipment.

loans.name: Reung

texts.en: Reung R., 35, is married and lives with four of her children and her husband in the Kampong Cham province of Cambodia. Since 1995, she has worked as construction worker and farmer to earn a living and is able to make $2.5 each day.  Her husband is a fisherman who catches fish fR. the lake and sells them to the market, earning around $5 a day.  Reung R. is asking a loan of $700 to purchase fishing tools for her husband and a cow to plow her farmland.

loans.use: To purchase fishing tools and a cow.

loans.name: Pierre

texts.fr: Né vers 1973 dans l’arrondissement de KESSOUNOU de la commune de DANGBO, monsieur   A. Pierre est marié et père de 5 enfants dont 3 scolarisés. Il est un cultivateur dans le village de GLAHOUNSA de la vallée de l’Ouémé et est membre du groupement   GM SENABLO DE GLAHOUNSA. Les habitants de ce village font les travaux champêtres à la décrue du fleuve ouémé. Leurs terres sont riches et les offrent un bon rendement.  Leurs spéculations principales sont la culture du maïs, du piment, des légumes, du gombo, de la tomate et du manioc qui sont des aliments de grande consommation au Bénin. Le problème de ces habitants riverains du fleuve est que, en période de crue, ils n’ont plus d’activité et dépensent tout le revenu issu de la campagne écoulée à la consommation. A la décrue ils n’ont plus d’argent pour payer la main d’œuvre indispensable pour emblaver la superficie à eux disponible.  La pratique dans le milieu qui consiste au bradage des récoltes ne les sécurise pas et les runes d’avantage. Cette pratique est la vente à un prix dérisoire de la récolte future à un nanti pour disposer de la somme nécessaire aux travaux champêtres. Fatigués de cette pratique il a sollicité un prêt de 180 000 FCFA pour l’exploitation d’environ 2hectares des spéculations susse indiquées.
texts.en:
Born around 1973 in the district of Kessounou in the town of Dangbo, Mr. Pierre A. is married and the father of 5 children, of whom 3 attend school. He is a farmer in the village of Glahounsa in the Ouémé valley and is a member of the GM Senablo group of Glahouna.

The inhabitants of this village work as farmers when the Ouémé River is low. Their land is rich and gives them a good harvest. Their principal crops are maize (corn), hot peppers, vegetables, okra, tomatoes, and manioc. The problem for these people who dwell along the river is that when the river is in flood, they have no more work and spend all the money they earned during the last farming season on foodstuffs. When the waters recede, they have no money left to pay laborers who are indispensible to them in getting their land sown.

The custom of borrowing against the new harvest does not make them more secure and indeed leaves them worse off. They sell their future harvest at a laughable price to weathier persons so that they have the cash needed to do their farming. Weary of this practice, Pierre A. has requested a loan of 180,000 F CFA which will allow him to farm about 2 hectares, growing the aforementioned crops.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: cultivating 2 hectares in corn and hot peppers

loans.name: Mwanne K.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 25-year-old Mwanne Chan’ga  from Mbarali. She is married with 3 children between the ages of 1 and 8. Mwanne buys crops from farmers and brings them at town where she can sell them at higher price. Mwanne has been running her crop business since 2002.  

She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 7 days per week and is assisted by her husband. Mwanne currently earns about $45 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of $425 USD to purchase more rice in bulk. In the future, she plans to expand her business by adding more quantity and range of the stock . Mwanne thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more rice in bulk

loans.name: Charity

texts.en:
Charity, 30 years old and the mother of two school-aged children, is currently in the business of transporting and selling charcoal with her husband.  She is requesting a loan to expand the business.    

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: En

texts.en: En N., 58, is a widow who lives with two of her children in the Kampong Cham province of Cambodia. She is a butcher who makes $5 a day.  She is also supported by her children, who work in garment factories.  She would like to take out a loan of $500 to purchase more pigs for her business. (She pictured with her daughter.)

loans.use: To purchase pigs for her shop.

loans.use: cultivating 2 hectares in corn (maize) and hot peppers

loans.name: Heang

texts.en: Heang S., 38, is a widow who lives with her three children in the Kampong Cham province of Cambodia. She does professional handicrafts. Since 1995, she been earning a living using beads and other materials to make flowers on woman clothes; she typically makes US$8 each day. People wear traditional decorated Khmer dresses during the Water Festival, P’chum Ben or Khmer New Year. It takes around 7-10 days to complete each dress and its price is expensive, too. Most of the people prefer handmade rather than machine-made decoration. She learned how to decorate from her mother and she started doing that business also before her marriage. Heang S. would like a loan of US$1200 to purchase more silk for decoration.

loans.use: To purchase more silk for decoration.

loans.name: In's Group

texts.en:
This is a loan for four borrowers all of whom are residents of Toultaek Commune in Battambang Province. The leader, Mrs. In N., 28, earns income from selling various kinds of groceries from her home. She started her business about 3 years ago. She looks after one lovely young child that attends school. Her husband, Sem Ratmony, age 37, drives a motorcycle taxi. In hopes to expand her business and is requesting a loan to purchase more groceries to store and resell.

Mrs. Prom S., 43, sells fruits and is requesting a loan to buy different kinds of fruits to sell.

Mrs. Suy V., 52, is a vegetable seller. She is requesting a loan to expand her business.

Mrs. Teng M., 33, sells clothes in the market and is now requesting a loan to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.use: To purchase groceries

loans.name: Ouy

texts.en: Ouy C., 44, is married and lives with her two children in the Kampong Cham province. She works in a grocery store, making around US$4 each day. Her husband is a taxi driver who makes about US$5 each day. Food prices have soared in the past year, as inflation has gotten out of control in Cambodia. Unfavorable climate conditions have also played a factor in making the price of rice very high. Ouy C. is asking for a loan of US$500 to add to her grocery’s inventory.

loans.use: To add her grocery’s inventory.

loans.name: Neema M.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 48-year-old Neema M. from Mbarali. She is married with 3 children between the ages of 9 and 17. She is also responsible for supporting two other dependants, because one is orphan and the other has parents, but they cannot take care for him. 

Neema buys crops from farmers and brings them at town where she can sell them at higher price. Neema  has been running her crop business since 2007. 

She works at her business for 9-12 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by her husband. She is requesting a loan of $650 USD to purchase more rice in bulk. In the future, she plans to expand her business by adding to the quantity and range of the stock . Neema thanks you for your support!

loans.use: To purchase more rice in bulk

loans.name: Sor

texts.en: Sor S. A., 37, is married and lives in the Kampong Cham province with her three children. She works in a grocery store, making around US$3 each day.  Her husband makes around US$5 each day as a blacksmith. Inflation has caused prices to soar in Cambodia and recent hikes in oil and rice prices have made for economic struggles for many Cambodians. Looking for ways to increase her income and combat rising expense costs, Sor S. A. has asked for a loan of US$700 to add to her grocery’s inventory and to raise pigs.

loans.use: To add to grocery inventory and raise pigs.

loans.name: Sourou

Il est un cultivateur dans le village de GLAHOUNSA de la vallée de l’Ouémé et est membre du groupement   GM SENABLO DE GLAHOUNSA. Born around 1965 in the district of Kessounou in the town of Dangbo, Mr. Sourou B. is married and the father of one child, who is not enrolled in school. He is a farmer in the village of Glahounsa in the Ouémé valley and is a member of the GM Senablo group of Glahounsa.

The inhabitants of this village work as farmers when the Ouémé River is low. Their land is rich and gives them a good harvest. Their principal crops are maize (corn), hot peppers, vegetables, okra, tomatoes, and manioc. The problem for these people who dwell along the river is that when the river is in flood, they have no more work and spend all the money they earned during the last farming season on foodstuffs.
