They sell their future harvest at a laughable price to weathier persons so that they have the cash needed to do their farming. Weary of this practice, Sourou B. has requested a loan of 130,000 F CFA which will allow him to farm about 1.5 hectares, growing the aforementioned crops.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: farming 1.5 hectares of land, growing maize (corn) and hot peppers

loans.name: Muyassarjon

texts.en:
Muyassarjon D. lives in the B.Gafurov region. She is married and the loving mother of 4 children. 

Mrs. D. works in the Khujand local bazaar where she sells children wear. She buys the assortment for herself in Istaravshan. She has a good assortment, so she sells clothing for boys and girls. She has a good reputation of being an honest and reliable trader. 

Mrs. D. has been a client of our program since 2006 and she is going to continue her cooperation with MicroInvest. Thanks to previous loans from MicroInvest, she opened her trade outlet and started a good business. 

Mrs. D. is applying to KIVA for a business development loan of 2500 STJ for 3 months to open one more trade outlet in another crowded bazaar. She thanks KIVA for its support.

loans.use: To open another trade outlet

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora J. sells cakes and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Flora is 30 years old and married. Her husband is a soldier. She has three children, who are all in school. With the extra capital from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services that are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To expand her business selling cakes.

loans.name: Cristina P.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 40-year-old Cristina K. from Mbarali. She married with five children between the ages of 2 and 15.Cristina has been running a maize business since 2000. She buys maize from farmers and brings them back to her town where she can sell them for a higher price. She works at her business for 9-12 hours per day, 7 days per week and is assisted by her husband. 

She is requesting a loan of 500 USD in order to purchase more maize in bulk. In the future, she plans to establish another business. Cristina thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more maize in bulk

loans.name: Dilbarjon

texts.en:
Dilbarjon K. lives in Khujand. She is 36 years old and the mother of 3 children. 

Mrs.K. is engaged in commercial service and trade. She started her business practically from scratch, but thanks to previous loans from MicroInvest, she opened a rather profitable business selling fruit. 

Mrs.K. sells bananas, oranges, grape, apples and mangoes that she imports from Russia and Uzbekistan. Recently, Mrs. K. finished her last loan payment from a previous MicroInvest loan. She is a very responsible client, so she has not any delays her loan repayment. Mrs. K. has worked with us since 2007 and she trusts the MicroInvest loan procedure. 

Mrs. K. is applying to KIVA for a business development loan of 3600 STJ for 6 months. She wants to take the next loan step and apply for a larger loan sum. She is going to increase her assortment in order to increase her business turnover, and open a new kind of business in future selling meat.

loans.use: To increase her assortment and to increase her business turnover

loans.name: Dilorom

texts.en:
Dilorom N. has been an active client of MicroInvest since 2002. The loan sums permanently increased her business turnover. 

Mrs. N. trades in the local bazaar. She has a good trade outlet that is located in the crowded part of the bazaar. Mrs. N. sells biscuits, sugar, sweets, candies and Swiss rolls that she imports from Russia, Uzbekistan and Kyrgyzstan. She has been engaged in sweets business for 3 years. 

Mrs. N. is applying to KIVA for a business support loan of 2000 STJ for 3 months to import sweets seasonal sales. Mrs.N. thanks KIVA for its support and wishes all the best.

loans.use: To import sweets

loans.name: Therese

texts.en:
Greetings from Therese N. in the northern province of Rwanda! Therese is 48 years old and married with three children.

She owns a small shop in Ruhengeri town. She sells domestic materials like soap, maize flour, cassava flour, matchboxes, salt, sugar, kilograms of beans, Colgate, paraffin, biscuits etc.

Besides shopping, Therese grows beans, wheat, and sweet potatoes, which are commonly grown in this area. From all her business activities, she earns about $105 per month. She employs two people to help her to run this business.

This entrepreneur is requesting for a loan of 515,000 Frws to buy more stock for her shop, because of the number of clients is increasing. This loan will be repaid in 8 months.

loans.use: Increase her stock

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret N. sells beer wholesale and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Margret is 50 years old and married. Her husband is a soldier. She has six children, who all go to school. With the extra capital from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services that are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: expand the business

loans.name: Amalia

texts.en:
“ I was able to give my children their desired education with the help of my husband, and I have never stopped dreaming,” Amelia said. Even though her children are grown, she continues to work hard to improve her family's living conditions.

Amalia lives at Barangay Malamag East Tumauini, Isabela. Their village is surrounded by farmland where villagers plant vegetables, corn and tobacco. It is also a flood-prone area, and when heavy rains come, water overflows in Cagayan River (the longest River in the Philippines) and passes through their area. Water reaches their house and oftentimes destroys their crops. She is married to Leon who owns a tricycle and also manages their farmland. They have two children namely: Eva (24 years old) and Lailanie (28 years old), both finished their vocational course in college.

She is requesting a loan to purchase additional stalls in the public market or in other villages and increase her stock of  rice and grocery items. This will increase her earnings. She says that in her experience, more blessings come her way whenever she works hard and continues to thank the Lord.

loans.use: To buy more market stalls and increase stock

loans.name: Donatien Pierre

loans.name: Edner

texts.en:
This is Edner B. B.. She is 36 years old and married with three children between the ages of 3 and 14 years. Edner is also responsible for supporting two dependents who depend on her because they are attendng school in the area. 

Edner has run a tailoring business since 2003. She is able to make different kinds of clothes with different designs. She work 6 days a week and 16 hours a day. Her business can produce a monthly profit of about $500 USD. 

Edner is requesting a loan of $825 USD to purchase an additional sewing machine and other materials for making clothes. In the future, she plans to open another business.

She thanks for your support.

The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. loans.use: To purchase an additional sewing machine and other materials for making clothes

loans.name: Precilla

texts.en:
Precilla S., a 49-year old mother of three children, never minds working double-time to earn a living and have enough food to share with her family. Her husband’s income from driving a family-owned tricycle would not suffice to meet their family expenditures and that’s why she started a hair parlor business.

Her business is situated in their house and the whole neighborhood is coming to her for hair treatments and new styles. She is requesting a loan to purchase additional materials for her hair parlor shop.

loans.use: To purchase additional materials for her hair parlor

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites M. has a passion for cooking. She enjoys preparing foods like noodles and simple snacks which she sells to her neighbors. She is married to Victor who works as a tricycle driver and also manages their farm.  They have three children: Marjorie – 20 years old, a college graduate; Jenny Rose – 18 years old, 2nd year college and Victor Jr. – 16 years old, 4th year high school student. 
 
Everyday, after doing household chores and preparing for the needs of her family, Marites various noodle dishes to sell.  Sometimes she also accepts orders from her customers.  Her little store is located next to her house. She is known for her excellent customer service

Marites  is requesting a loan to purchase items for her kitchen so she can improve her operation. She and her husband continue to work hard to have enough money to fully educate all their children. Marites says that a good education is the only wealth they can give to their children.

loans.use: To purchase kitchen items to improve cooking business

loans.name: Anne

texts.fr: Né vers 1973 dans l’arrondissement de HOUEDOME à AGONGUÊ de la commune de DANGBO, dame Z. Anne est mariée et mère de 3 enfants dont 1 scolarisé. Elle cultive dans le village de GLAHOUNSA de la vallée de l’Ouémé et est membre du groupement   GM SENABLO DE GLAHOUNSA. Les habitants de ce village font les travaux champêtres à la décrue du fleuve ouémé. Leurs terres sont riches et les offrent un bon rendement.  Leurs spéculations principales sont la culture du maïs, du piment, des légumes, du gombo, de la tomate et du manioc qui sont des aliments de grande consommation au Bénin. Fatigués de cette pratique elle a sollicité un prêt de 100 000 FCFA pour l’exploitation d’environ 1hectares des spéculations susse indiquées.
texts.en:
Born around 1973 in the district of Houedome, in Agongue in the town of Dangbo, Mrs. Anne Z. is married and the mother of 3 children, of whom one is enrolled in school. She is a farmer in the village of Glahounsa in the valley of the Ouémé River and is a member of the group GM Senablo of Glahounsa.

The inhabitants of this village work as farmers when the river level is low. Their land is rich and gives them a good harvest. Their principal crops are maize (corn), hot peppers, vegetables, okra, tomatoes, and manioc which are staple foods in Benin. The problem for these people who dwell along the river is that when the river is in flood, they have no more work and spend all the money they earned during the last farming season on foodstuffs. When the waters recede, they have no money left to pay for laborers who are indispensible to them in sowing their land. The custom of borrowing against the new harvest does not make them more secure and indeed leaves them worse off. They sell their future harvest at a laughable price to weathier persons so that they have the cash needed to do their farming. Weary of this practice, Anne Z. has requested a loan of 100,000 F CFA which will allow her to farm about 1 hectare, growing some of the aforementioned crops.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: cultivating 1 hectare in maize (corn) and hot peppers

loans.name: Bahry

texts.en:
Bahry O. was born in 1955 in the B.Gafurov region of Tajikistan. Now she lives and works in Khujand. 

Mrs. O. has been an active client of our program since 2007. She recommended herself as a responsible and reliable client who trusts the MicroInvest loan procedure. 

Mrs. O. applied to MicroInvest when she heard about her sister's succesful loan history. She took the loan so she could improve her business terms significantly. Afterward, she opened a trade outlet in which she sells eggs. Mrs. O. has been in business selling eggs for 11 years. She is a school teacher by professional background, so she engages in this low-cost work to have the additional family income. 

Now, Mrs. O. is applying to KIVA for a business support loan of 400 STJ for 1 month to make a trade counter.

loans.use: Trade counter

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario R. is 53 years old, married to Julio R., and lives in Maramag St. Centro Ilagan, Isabela. They are blessed with three children: Julie – 26 years old, a college graduate who works as a call center agent; Julio – 22 years old, a college graduate who works as a nurse; and Janica – 14 years old and in junior high school. 

Rosario says her Triple J canteen is situated in an urban area where there are many customers, especially during school days because many high school and college students come to her store. She is requesting a loan to purchase more and varied food items to sell in the canteen. This will increase her customers purchases and the number customers who come to her business.

“I dream to become a successful businesswoman someday so that I will be able to give my children a good future. That is why I really strive hard, “Rosario says. She hopes to open a grocery store next to her canteen.

loans.use: To expand the stock in her canteen

location.town: Maramag St. Centro Ilagan, Isabela, Isabela

loans.name: Félicienne

texts.fr: Né vers 1973 dans l’arrondissement de  KESSOUNOU de la commune de DANGBO, dame  A. Félicienne est mariée et mère de 6 enfants dont 3 scolarisés. Elle cultive dans le village de GLAHOUNSA de la vallée de l’Ouémé et est membre du groupement   GM SENABLO DE GLAHOUNSA. Les habitants de ce village font les travaux champêtres à la décrue du fleuve ouémé. Leurs terres sont riches et les offrent un bon rendement.  Leurs spéculations principales sont la culture du maïs, du piment, des légumes, du gombo, de la tomate et du manioc qui sont des aliments de grande consommation au Bénin. Le problème de ces habitants riverains du fleuve est que, en période de crue, ils n’ont plus d’activité et dépensent tout le revenu issu de la campagne écoulée à la consommation. A la décrue ils n’ont plus d’argent pour payer la main d’œuvre indispensable pour emblaver la superficie à eux disponible.  La pratique dans le milieu qui consiste au bradage des récoltes ne les sécurise pas et les runes d’avantage. Cette pratique est la vente à un prix dérisoire de la récolte future à un nanti pour disposer de la somme nécessaire aux travaux champêtres. Fatigués de cette pratique elle a sollicité un prêt de 100 000 FCFA pour l’exploitation d’environ 1hectares des spéculations susse indiquées.
texts.en:
Born around 1973 in the district of Kessounou, in the town of Dangbo, Mrs. Félicienne A. is married and the mother of 6 children, of whom three are enrolled in school. She is a farmer in the village of Glahounsa in the valley of the Ouémé River and is a member of the group GM Senablo of Glahounsa.

The inhabitants of this village work as farmers when the river level is low. Their land is rich and gives them a good harvest. Their principal crops are maize (corn), hot peppers, vegetables, okra, tomatoes, and manioc which are staple foods in Benin. The problem for these people who dwell along the river is that when the river is in flood, they have no more work and spend all the money they earned during the last farming season on foodstuffs. When the waters recede, they have no money left to pay for laborers who are indispensible to them in sowing their land. The custom of borrowing against the new harvest does not make them more secure and indeed leaves them worse off. They sell their future harvest at a laughable price to weathier persons so that they have the cash needed to do their farming. Weary of this practice, Félicienne A. has requested a loan of 100,000 F CFA which will allow her to farm about 1 hectare, growing some of the aforementioned crops.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: cultivating 1 hectare in maize (corn) and hot peppers

loans.name: Nazira

texts.en:
Nazira A. is 52 years old. She is married with three adult children. For almost for 10 years, Nazira has had a beauty salon. Every day, she services many brides. She offers bridal dresses, manicures, pedicures, make-up and hair styles. Her salon is always full of clients, because she does her job professionally. 

She wants to take a loan to expand her business. She wants to buy additional equipment and hire an employee. Nazira likes her job very much, because she likes to see the smiles of happy brides every day.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is one of the poorer of the 15 former Soviet republics, with a GDP per capita of less than $600. The civil war, which took place soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., severely damaged the already weak economic infrastructure and caused a sharp decline in agricultural production and the manufacturing sector.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  All of these factors have resulted in a severe lack of jobs and have forced hundreds of thousands to leave Tajikistan to find work in other countries, mostly in Russia.  While Tajikistan has experienced some economic growth since the end of the Civil War, nearly two-thirds of the population still lives in abject poverty. 

IMON International's mission is to promote sustainable economic development and improved quality of life in Tajikistan by insuring reliable access to financial services for the economically active members of the population. IMON International has 8 branch offices throughout Tajikistan and their entrepreneurs work in many parts of the country's economic sector including trade, manufacturing, agriculture, and services. As of  October 2008, IMON International had 27,802 active clients and a total portfolio of $28,405,549.  Approximately 44% of these clients are women and 65% are from rural areas.  To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing goods for her beauty shop

loans.name: Céline

texts.fr: Né vers 1973 dans l’arrondissement de  KESSOUNOU de la commune de DANGBO, dame   S. A. Céline est mariée et mère de 6 enfants dont 1 scolarisé. Elle cultive dans le village de GLAHOUNSA de la vallée de l’Ouémé et est membre du groupement   GM SENABLO DE GLAHOUNSA. Les habitants de ce village font les travaux champêtres à la décrue du fleuve ouémé. Leurs terres sont riches et les offrent un bon rendement.  Leurs spéculations principales sont la culture du maïs, du piment, des légumes, du gombo, de la tomate et du manioc qui sont des aliments de grande consommation au Bénin. Le problème de ces habitants riverains du fleuve est que, en période de crue, ils n’ont plus d’activité et dépensent tout le revenu issu de la campagne écoulée à la consommation. A la décrue ils n’ont plus d’argent pour payer la main d’œuvre indispensable pour emblaver la superficie à eux disponible.  La pratique dans le milieu qui consiste au bradage des récoltes ne les sécurise pas et les runes d’avantage. Cette pratique est la vente à un prix dérisoire de la récolte future à un nanti pour disposer de la somme nécessaire aux travaux champêtres. Fatigués de cette pratique elle a sollicité un prêt de 100 000 FCFA pour l’exploitation d’environ 1hectares des spéculations susse indiquées.
texts.en:
Born around 1973 in the district of Kessounou, in the town of Dangbo, Mrs. Céline S. A. is married and the mother of 6 children, of whom one is enrolled in school. She is a farmer in the village of Glahounsa in the valley of the Ouémé River and is a member of the group GM Senablo of Glahounsa.

The inhabitants of this village work as farmers when the river level is low. Their land is rich and gives them a good harvest. Their principal crops are maize (corn), hot peppers, vegetables, okra, tomatoes, and manioc which are staple foods in Benin. The problem for these people who dwell along the river is that when the river is in flood, they have no more work and spend all the money they earned during the last farming season on foodstuffs. When the waters recede, they have no money left to pay for laborers who are indispensible to them in sowing their land.

The custom of borrowing against the new harvest does not make them more secure and indeed leaves them worse off. They sell their future harvest at a laughable price to weathier persons so that they have the cash needed to do their farming. Weary of this practice, Céline S. A. has requested a loan of 100,000 F CFA which will allow her to farm about 1 hectare, growing some of the aforementioned crops.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: cultivating 1 hectare in maize (corn) and hot peppers

loans.name: Mary Gay Rose

texts.en:
In a village where unity and cooperation are manifested through active participation during the yearly festival, you will find a sari-sari store (a community based store) owned by Marie Gay Rose R.. 

Marie Gay, 40, lives in the village of Magsaysay Naguillan, Isabela and is married to Perlito who drives heavy equipment for a local construction firm. They are blessed with two children: Mary Anne – 14 years old and a sophomore high school, and Merjohn Gayle – 5 years old.

Aside from having a sari-sari store (a common term for a small village store), Marie also has a direct selling business. Being a hard-working business woman, Marie Gay works in her store, located next to her house, from 6am to 8pm. She sells variety of products commonly used by villagers. Most of her products are canned goods, snack foods, bottled spices, perfumes, sleepers, shoes, and other items.

Marie Gay is requesting a loan so she can expand and improve her business. More stock will enable her to service more customers. She is working to earn enough money for her childrens' eduction, including college.

loans.use: To increase the stock in her store

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth S. is a 56-year-old married woman with seven children who range in age from 20 to 34. She also has one orphaned dependent. Elizabeth has been operating a popcorn business since 2001, drying maize grain under a special machine to produce the treat which is especially popular with children. She works seven days a week and eight hours a day, and is now requesting a loan of $255 in order to purchase an additional machine and more maize.

Elizabeth thanks you for your support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase an additional corn drying machine and more maize.

loans.name: Cornelia

texts.en:
Cornelia M. is married to Pedro, a simple farmer. They had five children, but one of them died in an accident. Cornelia says this inspired her to work even harder to provide for her remaining 4 children:  Judy Mae -- 9 months old, Jaypee -- 6 years old and in elementary, Joan -- 16 years old and in high school, and the eldest daughter Kate Lyn-- 18 years old and a high school graduate.

Cornelia is a resident of Barangay of Tumauini, Isabela where the clean and green project is one of the major projects of the Barangay Council. Every resident is encouraged to have their own backyard garden planting different kinds of vegetables for food sustainability. Cornelia describes their community as small but probably the cleanest Barangay in their municipality. 

Cornelia sells rice and her well-known, homemade rice cakes in her community. She is requesting a loan to buy rice, coconut, and brown sugar for her rice business and to buy a piglet for her backyard pig raising business.

“I dream that all my children will finish college so they will have a better opportunity for a good future," she says. Expanding her business will help this dream come true.

loans.use: To purchase rice, cocanut, and sugar for rice business and to purchase a piglet for pig-raising business

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 43-year-old Mariam A. M. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with four children, between the ages of 20 and 26. Mariam has been running a bar business since 2004. She works at the business for 16 hours per day, 7 days per week, and she is assisted by three employees. Mariam currently earns about $250 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of $1050 USD in order to purchase additional stocks of beer, soda and drinking water. In the future, she plans to increase her variety of stock. Mariam thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of beer, soda and drinking water

loans.name: Nasiba

texts.en:
B. Nasiba, 36 and married, begins work very early each day in order to get ahead and achieve her goal of having her five children finish school and enter University. B. sells footwear and clothes for men in the central market of Penjikent town and, thanks to the support of her spouse and her own efforts, has been able to develop her business to the point where she operates it from a large space and with a substantial clientèle. Requesting a loan of $600 which she will repay in 8 months, she plans to buy a greater variety of winter boots and meet some specific requests from her customers.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International: Tajikistan is one of the poorest of the 15 former Soviet republics, with a GDP per capita of less than $600. The civil war, which took place soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., severely damaged the already weak economic infrastructure and caused a sharp decline in the agricultural and manufacturing sectors. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. All of these factors have resulted in a severe lack of jobs and have forced hundreds of thousands to leave Tajikistan to find work in other countries, mostly in Russia. While Tajikistan has experienced some economic growth since the end of the Civil War, nearly two-thirds of the population still lives in abject poverty.

IMON International's mission is to promote sustainable economic development and improved quality of life in Tajikistan by insuring reliable access to financial services for the economically active members of the population. IMON International has eight branch offices throughout Tajikistan and their entrepreneurs work in many parts of the country's economic sector including trade, manufacturing, agriculture, and services. As of October 2008, IMON International had 27,802 active clients and a total portfolio of $28,405,549. Approximately 44% of these clients are women and 65% are from rural areas. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase winter boots for men in order to increase the range of goods for sale.

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice T. is the 32-year-old mother of one kid who is currently in school. She is very supportive to her husband in taking care of their kid. She has been operating a seamstress shop for the past eight years. She trains 3 young ladies in sewing to equip them with skills and experience for their future careers. She sews all forms female wears with various kinds of styles like kaba and slit, wedding dresses, funeral clothes, etc. She wants to use the loan to buy more sewing materials like linen, threads, thimbles, etc. to increase her output and efficiency. She hopes to increase her savings to support her kid's schoo expenses.

She is a member of the community group called “Boldness” Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee and support one another to repay their loans. The group members guarantee a loan through repayment pledge and support one another to repay the loan. She does not sell on group meeting days and her picture was taken during her group meeting.

loans.use: To buy more sewing material like linen, threads, thimbles, etc.

loans.name: Makhfira

texts.en:
D. Makhfira is 47 years old. She is married and the loving mother of 5 children. Makhfira owns a successful clothing and shoe sales business at the market of Penjikent, Tajikistan. She has been doing this business for about 8 years. Her business has benefited from a good sales location and constant demand for her products. Makhfira tries to offer good prices to her customers while still making a profit. A normal monthly income from her business is around 1500 Somoni.

Makhfira has requested a loan of 3500 Somoni with the term of 8 months to increase her product inventory. This is a busy time for many market vendors as the cold season is coming and everyone is preparing for winter. By purchasing additional inventory, Makhfira will be better prepared to meet the increased demand and earn a good income. We believe her persistent work and natural liveliness will help her continue to succeed in her trade and repay this loan on time.

loans.use: Increase working capital

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary L. is thirty-four years old. She is married with three kids who are currently in school. Mary is a dealer in electronic parts like electrical cables, transistors, transformers, screw drivers, wires, television cords, antennas, etc. She assists in providing good service to her customers. She buys her supplies from importers at wholesale prices and gives to her customers at retail prices. She requests the loan to enable her procure an increased stock of electronic parts. She hopes to increase her savings and expand her shop to include refrigerators and other electrical parts. She belongs to the community group called Boldness Trust Group. In this group, members agree to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan. She does not sell on group meeting days and her picture was taken during her group meeting.

loans.use: To procure increased stock of electrical and electronic parts.

loans.name: Abiba

texts.en: Abiba A. is 33 years old. She is married and has three children.Since she has not been to school, she is trying  to send all her children to school so that they can have a better future. Abiba has sold porridge in her neighborhood for fourteen years now. Porridge is one of the local foods enjoyed as breakfast. It is prepared from milled maize or millet grains, boiled and taken with sugar, milk and bread. With a large customer base, Abiba wants to use the loan of $425 to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, millet, firewood, sugar and milk to increase production. She hopes to have a better income to support her kids in school. She is a member of group called Boldness Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loans and provide peer pressure to repay the loan. Abiba does not sell on group meeting days and her picture was taken during her group meeting.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials like bags of maize, millet, sugar, and milk etc.

loans.name: Farida

texts.en:
Hello from Tanzania! This is 43 year old Farida F. M. from Dar es Salaam. She is divorced with 4 children between the ages of 10 and 23.  Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one 14 year old who is dependent because she is an orphan. Farida has been running a duka business, since 2005. The business is a grocery business where Farida sells rice and cooking oils. She works at the business for 10 hours per day, 7 days per week and is assisted by her children. Farida currently earns about $250 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of $500 in order to purchase additional stocks of sugar, rice, wheat flour, salt and other small items for her grocery. In the future, she plans to open another business. Farida thanks you for your support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy sugar, rice, wheat flour, salt and other small items for her grocery.

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
“I was able to support and finish the schooling of my two children through my community-based store.  I managed it well and that is why I was able to earn more income,” Rosario said humbly. 

Rosario lives in Barangay Magassi Cabagan, Isabela.  She settled there after she got married to Marcos. She came from a neighboring community and eventually learned to mingle and adjust to her new environment. His husband manages and works in their small rice and corn fields. They are blessed with two children; Romar, 23 years old, who has graduated from vocational course and their eldest daughter Juana who is an OFW (Overseas Filipina worker) works as a factory worker in abroad.

For ten years, the earnings from her general store has supported her children's education and their daily living expenses. But Rosario still wants to get a loan of $225 of additional working capital to purchase additional stocks like noodles, sugar, coffee, and canned goods like sardines, meat and beef loaf, corned beef, soft drinks, beans, chicken, eggs etc. 

Since her children are no longer studying, all her loan proceeds will be put into her business to have more products for her fellow villagers.

“We work very hard for our future because our eldest daughter Juana is planning to marry.  We do not want to ask for the support of our daughter when she gets married.   I also dream that  our store will become a grocery store someday,” Rosario says.

loans.use: To buy additional products for her store

loans.name: Khursandoy

texts.en:
Khursandoy H. is a widow living in Penjikent, Tajikistan with her only son. Khursandoy runs a small business selling men’s shoes and clothing in the local market. She has been involved in this trade for 12 years. She recently moved her vending facility to a different location which has brought an increase in her sales.  Khursandoy has many loyal customers. She is very friendly and amiable with each client, thus Khursandoy has a unique talent of attracting new customers. Khursandoy purchases clothing wholesale every week. She is hoping to use the loan of $750 to purchase winter clothing and shoes for men. She hopes to see her venture grow big enough to afford to buy a new vending facility in the future.  

Tajikistan is one of the poorer of the 15 former Soviet republics, with a GDP per capita of less than $600. The civil war, which took place soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., severely damaged the already weak economic infrastructure and caused a sharp decline in agricultural production and the manufacturing sector.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  All of these factors have resulted in a severe lack of jobs and have forced hundreds of thousands to leave Tajikistan to find work in other countries, mostly in Russia.  While Tajikistan has experienced some economic growth since the end of the civil war, nearly two-thirds of the population still lives in abject poverty. 

IMON International's mission is to promote sustainable economic development and improved quality of life in Tajikistan by insuring reliable access to financial services for the economically active members of the population. IMON International has 8 branch offices throughout Tajikistan and their entrepreneurs work in many parts of the country's economic sector including trade, manufacturing, agriculture, and services. As of October 2008, IMON International had 27,802 active clients and a total portfolio of $28,405,549.  Approximately 44% of these clients are women and 65% are from rural areas.  To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy winter shoes and clothing for men for sale

loans.name: Rejoice

texts.en:
Rejoice, 29 years old, married to a civil engineer and the mother of two children, both attending school, is currently in the business of selling beer at the bar and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Rejoice hopes that the extra profits accruing from the loan will allow her to further expand the business in the near future.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more beer for sale.

loans.name: Sanobar

texts.en:
Sanobar M. is 45 years old. She works purchasing and reselling cows with her husband. She has 3 children, two of whom are already students. Sanobar would like to request a loan of $ 750 for the term of 12 months in order to purchase additional cows to increase her inventory and to meet customer demand. She believes this will lead to greater revenue and, ultimately, greater profit for her family. In the future, she would like to reinvest the earnings generated by this loan back into her business to purchase additional cows and to increase their income further. Sanobar and her husband plan to use the increased income to fund their children’s education.  

About Tajikistan: 

Tajikistan is one of the poorer of the 15 former Soviet republics, with a GDP per capita of less than $600. The civil war, which took place soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., severely damaged the already weak economic infrastructure and caused a sharp decline in agricultural production and the manufacturing sector.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  All of these factors have resulted in a severe lack of jobs and have forced hundreds of thousands to leave Tajikistan to find work in other countries, mostly in Russia.  While Tajikistan has experienced some economic growth since the end of the Civil War, nearly two-thirds of the population still lives in abject poverty. 

About IMON International: 

IMON International's mission is to promote sustainable economic development and improved quality of life in Tajikistan by insuring reliable access to financial services for the economically active members of the population. IMON International has 8 branch offices throughout Tajikistan and their entrepreneurs work in many parts of the country's economic sector including trade, manufacturing, agriculture, and services. As of October 2008, IMON International had 27,802 active clients and a total portfolio of $28,405,549.  Approximately 44% of these clients are women and 65% are from rural areas.

loans.use: To purchase cattle for sale.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret O. is 30 years old. She is married with two children who attend school. She owns and operates a soft drink shop and sells items like canned foods. Margaret buys bulk supplies of canned foods and bottled drinks like Coke, Fanta, Pepsi, malt etc. in the local market. She would like to use the loan to buy increased supplies of canned foods and drinks to expand her business. Margaret hopes to earn additional income from the increased business which will enable her revive business growth and provide her children with a quality education. She belongs to a community organization called ‘Boldness Trust Group’. The group members provide loan guarantees through a repayment pledge and assist one another in repaying loans. She does not sell on group meeting days and her picture was taken during her group meeting.

loans.use: To buy supplies of canned foods and bottled drinks like Coke, Fanta, Pepsi, malt etc.

loans.name: Nuriddin

texts.en:
N. Nuriddin is 51 years old and was born in Penjikent, Tajikistan. He is the father of three children, and his main work consists of breeding cattle. This very remunerative activity enables him to provide for the needs of his family. A very ambitious man, he would like to buy a greater number of cattle, and to build a farmhouse to house them in order to ensure their safety. Due to a lack of finances, he is asking for a loan of 500 Somoni ($ 150 USD) for the realization of this project. He promises to repay the loan in 12 months. When his dream is carried out, he will be able to have a greater source of revenue for his growing family. With your help this will be possible. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and the birthplace of the great Persian poet Rudaki and the most famous Islamic philosopher Ibn Sina (Avicenna). The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of the cattle and the small cattle to expand the business.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama S., a 35-year-old trader, is married with three kids. All of them are currently in school. She trades in cereals like maize, beans, tubers of yam, and rice on top of a table in the local market of Abeka in Accra. She requests the loan to enable her buy increased stock of maize and rice to grow her business and scale up sales. Ama has being in this business for the past 2 years without any regret for what she does. She says her major challenge has to do with the kids’ school fees. She hopes to increase her savings to support the children education to give them better future career opportunities. Ama said she lives because of them.

She belongs to the community group called Boldness Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral and assist one another to repay the loan. She does not sell on group meeting days and her picture was taken during her group meeting.

loans.use: To buy more maize and rice.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen A. is engaged in the sari-sari (a variety store) business in her community. She is 31 years old and married to Franklin Sr., who works as a driver. They have two healthy children: John Loyd, 4 years old and Franklin Jr., 1 year old.  Although her husband is working, their income is still insufficient to meet the growing needs of their family.  This is the reason why she put up a small store which could generate additional income for them.

Some of the things that she sells in her store are basic commodities such as sugar, cooking oil, bread, candies and toiletries.  She is requesting additional funding which amounts to Php5,000.00 to purchase additional items to sell in her store.

Throughout almost seven years in the business, Helen has been earning a gross weekly income of only Php2, 500.00 which she must budget to sustain their daily expenses and the operational cost of her store.   

She envisions herself as a successful businesswoman, but she knows that it can only happen if her business will continue to improve and eventually grow big. She always dreams to have the best for her family because their welfare is her utmost concern. “Just be strong and patient in every challenge in order to succeed in life,” added Helen. 

Helen assures the lender that she will pay her weekly loan payments on time because she knows how important trust is, especially when she knows that this is an opportunity for the business growth that she always dreams of.

loans.use: additional items for her store

loans.name: James

texts.fr: Né vers 1968 dans l’arrondissement de KESSOUNOU de la commune de DANGBO au Bénin, monsieur B. James est marié et père de 5 enfants dont 2 scolarisés. Il est un cultivateur dans le village de HÊTIN SOTA où se trouve la source thermale de DANGBO dans la vallée de l’Ouémé et est membre du groupement    GH MIWANOU DE HÊTIN SOTA. Les habitants de ce village font les travaux champêtres à la décrue du fleuve ouémé. Leurs terres sont riches et les offrent un bon rendement.  Leurs spéculations principales sont la culture du maïs, du piment, des légumes, du gombo, de la tomate et du manioc qui sont des aliments de grande consommation au Bénin. Le problème de ces habitants riverains du fleuve est que, en période de crue, ils n’ont plus d’activité et dépensent tout le revenu issu de la campagne écoulée à la consommation. A la décrue ils n’ont plus d’argent pour payer la main d’œuvre indispensable pour emblaver la superficie à eux disponible.  La pratique dans le milieu qui consiste au bradage des récoltes ne les sécurise pas et les runes d’avantage. Cette pratique est la vente à un prix dérisoire de la récolte future à un nanti pour disposer de la somme nécessaire aux travaux champêtres. Fatigués de cette pratique il a sollicité un prêt de 175 000 FCFA pour l’exploitation d’environ 2hectares des spéculations susse indiquées.
texts.en:
Born around 1968 in the district of Kessounou in the town of Dangbo in Bénin, Mr. James B. is married and the father of 5 children, of whom 2 are enrolled in school. He is a farmer in the village of Hetin Sota where the hot springs of Dangbo are located, in the valley of the Ouémé River, and he is a member of the group GM Miwanou of Hetin Sota.

The inhabitants of this village work as farmers when the river level is low. Their land is rich and gives them a good harvest. Their principal crops are maize (corn), hot peppers, vegetables, okra, tomatoes, and manioc which are staple foods in Bénin. The problem for these people who dwell along the river is that when the river is in flood, they have no more work and spend all the money they earned during the last farming season on foodstuffs. When the waters recede, they have no money left to pay for laborers who are indispensible to them in sowing the land.

The custom of borrowing against the new harvest does not make them more secure and indeed leaves them worse off. They sell their future harvest at a laughable price to weathier persons so that they have the cash needed to do their farming. Weary of this practice, James B. has requested a loan of 175,000 F CFA which will allow him to farm about 2 hectares, growing some of the aforementioned crops.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: cultivating 2 hectares in corn (maize) and hot peppers

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana believes in this philosophy: “Nothing is impossible with God. Through faith and hard work, they will be able to survive the challenges of life.” 

Susana is married to Renato who is known in their village as a painter of houses and buildings. They have three children: Rhea Joyce - 11 years old, first year high school; Rosalie, 10 years old, an elementary student; and Ryan, 4 years old. They live happily in Barangay Minallo Naguillan, Isabela, two kilometers away from the national highway. The village is a small, agricultural-based community where the farming of rice and corn comprises the major sources of living among the villagers. 

Raising hogs is Susana's business. “I choose this because, while I’m managing our hogs, I can still take good care of my family, and at the same time, I can help my husband in supporting the daily needs of our family since his income as a painter and as a farmer is not enough,” Susana added.

To further improve her business, Susana will need additional capital amounting to PHP4, 000. She will buy additional piglets and feed supply. She also plans to engage in the business of purchase and sale in order to have an alternative source of income. Moreover, she plans to save some of her income for emergency purposes, for education for her children and for their everyday needs.

loans.use: Additional piglets and feed

loans.name: Cristeta

texts.en:
“Being a normal housewife who is engaged in a small enterprise, I believe that the money that I will borrow will help me generate an income which will help my husband to raise the needed money for our daily living,” Cristeta said.

Cristeta M. lives at Barangay Malamag East Tumauini, Isabela. The village is a relatively small and progressive community. She is married to Servillano who is a general farmer. They have four children, namely: 8-year-old Arnel and 12-year-old Servillano Jr., both of whom are elementary school students; 17-year-old Grace, who is a high school student; and the eldest child, 18-year-old Marvie who is a high school graduate.

Cristeta wants to borrow Php4,000 to buy two piglets, animal feed and vaccines. She also wants to repair her own backyard pigpen, so that she can add more piglets.
  
Her ultimate dream in life is to be able to support the college education of her two youngest sons.

loans.use: piglets, feed, vaccines and pigpen repair

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en:
Christiana Q. is a 27-year-old single mother of one child. At the moment, her kid is in school. 

For three years, she has been selling, through hawking, washing detergents, such as Unilever and Omo washing powders, soaps, bleaches, etc.. She balances her stock on her head and walks miles to sell to her customers at their doorsteps. She needs the loan to enable her make progress in her business. Christiana wants to use the loan to buy more supplies of detergents. By increasing her stock, she hopes to make more income to provide her child with a good education. 

She is a member of the group called Ephesians Trust Group. Members in this group guarantee one another and assist each other to repay the loan. She does not sell on group meeting days and her picture was taken during her group meeting.

loans.use: To buy more supplies, detergents like Omo, Parazone, bleach and soaps etc.

loans.name: Sara

texts.en:
Sara P. sells tomatoes and is requesting a loan to pay school fees for her children. Sara is 30 years old and married. Her husband is a businessman. She has five children, who all go to school. With the extra capital from her loan, she hopes to be able to send her children to school.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services that are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Marymary

texts.en:
Mary J. sells drugs at her pharmacy and is requesting a loan to stock more drugs to sell. Mary is 30 years old and married. Her husband is a police officer. She has two children, who both go to school. With the extra capital from her loan, she hopes to be able to stock more drugs for sale at her pharmacy.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services that are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. loans.use: To stock more drugs for sale.

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella A. S. is a 39-year-old mother of two, who are currently in school. The elder one, a son, is now in his fourth year at the medical school of the University of Science and Technology Ghana. 

She is very supportive to her husband in taking care of her children in school. She has been operating a seamstress shop for the past five years. She is training one young lady in sewing to equip her with the skills and experience for a future career. She sews all forms of women's wear with various kinds of styles like kaba and slit (a variation of the European long skirt and tailored top), wedding dress, funeral clothes, etc. 

She wants to use the loan to buy more sewing material like linen, threads, thimbles, etc., in order to increase her output and efficiency. She hopes to increase savings to support the kids in school. She is a member of the community group called “Boldness” Trust Group. Members in this group guarantee and support one another to repay their loans. She does not sell on group meeting days and her picture was taken during her group meeting.

loans.use: To buy more sewing materials like linen, threads, thimbles, etc.

loans.name: Sweetie Pie

texts.en:
Our applicant is known as Sweetie Pie and, as her name implies, she is a lovable woman.  She runs a sari-sari store, a community-based business that sells a variety of items in high demand in her area. Her husband is employed as a local agent for a distributing company based in their town. They have three children: Hersal, 18 years old and a third-year college student; Charmaine, 18 years old, a second-year nursing student; and Dennies Kae, 12 years old, a first-year high school student. They live in the village of Magsaysay, which is a few kilometers from the highway and near the local city hall. The village is known for rapid development and for its peaceful and orderly nature.

Her small store is open from 6:00 in the morning until 7:00 in the evening.  Sweetie Pie decided to open her store because her husband's income is not large enough to support all the educational needs of their children.
  
At present, Sweetie Pie is using her income to pay for the cost of having two children in college. She is seeking a loan to buy additional inventory for her store, including soft drinks, cooking oil, sugar, vinegar, canned foods and other items.  By expanding her business, she will be able to help her husband meeting more of the family's expenses.

loans.use: to buy additional products to sell in  her store

loans.name: Madeleine

They sell their future harvest at a laughable price to weathier persons so that they have the cash needed to do their farming. Weary of this practice, Madeleine A. has requested a loan of 150,000 F CFA which will allow her to farm about 2 hectares, growing some of the aforementioned crops.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: cultivating 2 hectares in corn and hot peppers

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah A. has been selling used clothes for the last 10 years in the marketplace in her town of Accra, Ghana. She relies on the income she makes from her sales to pay her household's food and utility bills. Sarah is 36 years old, married and the mother of three children who are in school. She is applying for this loan to buy more clothing to sell to her customers. Her long-term goal is to save enough money to send her children to college. She is a member of a local organization know as the Israel Trust Group. Members of this group guarantee and provide support to one another when it comes to repaying loans. Sarah does not sell on group meeting days, but we were able to take her picture during her group meeting. Sarah says she would be most grateful for your assistance

loans.use: To buy more clothing to resell

loans.name: Bernice

texts.fr: Née vers 1973 à  WOZOUME  dans la commune de DANGBO, dame  K. Bernice est mariée et mère de 6enfants dont 3 scolarisés. Elle cultive dans le village de  HÊTIN SOTA  de la vallée de l’Ouémé et est membre du groupement  GF MAHUKPEGO DE HÊTIN SOTA ; elle vend aussi du maïs et de l’huile de palme. Les habitants de ce village font les travaux champêtres à la décrue du fleuve ouémé. Leurs terres sont riches et les offrent un bon rendement.  Leurs spéculations principales sont la culture du maïs, du piment, des légumes, du gombo, de la tomate et du manioc qui sont des aliments de grande consommation au Bénin. Le problème de ces habitants riverains du fleuve est que, en période de crue, ils n’ont plus d’activité et dépensent tout le revenu issu de la campagne écoulée à la consommation. A la décrue ils n’ont plus d’argent pour payer la main d’œuvre indispensable pour emblaver la superficie à eux disponible.  La pratique dans le milieu qui consiste au bradage des récoltes ne les sécurise pas et les runes d’avantage. Cette pratique est la vente à un prix dérisoire de la récolte future à un nanti pour disposer de la somme nécessaire aux travaux champêtres. Fatigués de cette pratique elle a sollicité un prêt de 150 000 FCFA pour l’exploitation d’environ 2hectares des spéculations susse indiquées.

Born around 1973 in Wozoume, in the township of Dangbo, Mrs. Bernice K. is married and the mother of 6 children, of whom three are enrolled in school. She is a farmer in the village of Hetin Sota in the valley of the Ouémé River and is a member of the group GF Mahukpego of Hetin Sota. She also sells corn (maize) and palm oil.

The inhabitants of this village work as farmers when the river level is low. Their land is rich and gives them a good harvest. Their principal crops are maize (corn), hot peppers, vegetables, okra, tomatoes, and manioc which are staple foods in Benin. The problem for these people who dwell along the river is that when the river is in flood, they have no more work and spend all the money they earned during the last farming season on foodstuffs. When the waters recede, they have no money left to pay for laborers who are indispensible to them in sowing their land. The custom of borrowing against the new harvest does not make them more secure and indeed leaves them worse off. They sell their future harvest at a laughable price to weathier persons so that they have the cash needed to do their farming. Weary of this practice, Bernice K. has requested a loan of 150,000 F CFA which will allow her to farm about 2 hectares, growing some of the aforementioned crops.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: cultivating 2 hectares in corn (maize) and hot peppers

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose N. sells charcoal, beans, and cooking oil and is requesting a loan to construct a house to rent. Rose is 29 years old and widowed. She has six children and they all go to school. With the extra capital from her loan, she hopes to be able to construct a house for rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services that are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To construct a house to rent.

loans.name: Mayasa

texts.en:
Greetings from Tanzania! This is 45-year-old Mayasa S. M., who lives in Dar es Salaam. She is married and has three children who are between the ages of 24 and 28. Mayasa has been running a restaurant since 2004. She works at this business for 14 hours a day, six days a week and has four employees. Mayasa currently earns about $100 a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of $425 to purchase food containers. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Mayasa thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, which is why they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future

loans.use: To buy food containers.

loans.name: Veronika H.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 22-year-old Veronika N. from Mbarali. She is married with one child, aged three. Veronika has been running a rice business since 2007. She buys rice from local farmers and resells it in town. She works at her business for 9-12 hours a day, 6 days a week and receives help from her husband. She is requesting a loan of $625 to buy rice in bulk. In the future, she plans to open another business. Veronika thanks you for your support!

loans.name: Rizalyn

texts.en:
Rizalyn T. believes that “discipline is the backbone of progress," and has made that the guiding principle in life.   

She is 27 years old and married to Pether, who works as a farmer. They are blessed with two children: Charizze, who is 5 years old and in a pre-school program and Pether John, who is 2 years old. They live in Binarzang Quirino, Isabela, a section of the country where rice and corn are major crops. Her family lives happily in the village and she works hard to maintain their close family ties. 

Rizalyn has a modest village store where she earns a small income that pays for their daily needs and the children's school fees. They also invest some of her earnings in the maintenance of their farm. 

Rizalyn has applied for a loan to buy additional items to sell in her store.  This loan will be of great help to her since she will be able to increase her income. This will help her husband buy farm supplies and save for the education of their children and the future of her family . 

“I believe that my dreams will turn into reality if I will work hard and hand in hand with my husband,” Rizalyn explained.

loans.use: Additional products to sell in her store

loans.name: Phidel

texts.fr: Ce brave monsieur vend du poisson au quai de pêche de Boudody. Grâce à cette activité, il arrive à entretenir ses 4 enfants. Il sollicite ce crédit pour acheter des bacs afin d'augmenter sa capacité de stocker du poisson. Il a une expérience avérée dans le secteur.
texts.en:
This courageous man sells fish on the Boudody fishing dock. Thanks to this activity he is able to provide for his four children. He is requesting this loan to buy tubs in order to increase his ability to stock fish. He has a solid experience in this business.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fish

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret A. is 30 years old and married with five children. She sells foodstuffs like yams and plantain. She hopes to expand her business. She needs the loan amount of N40, 000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thank you to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia A. is a 30-year-old trader. She is married with three children. She has been selling used clothes in the local market of Teshie in Accra for seven years. With income from her business, Patricia is supporting two of her kids in junior high school while the last-born is still breastfeeding.

Her major business challenge over the years has to do with funds to scale up the business, especially in this crucial election period in Ghana. She has lots of marketing experience with a strong customer base as compared to her competitors and very confident that the loan would enable her to achieve remarkable business progress. She wants to use the loan to buy more bales of used clothes from the importers to serve her customers. She hopes to save enough to support her kids to complete school. She is a member of the group called Israel Trust Group. Members in this group guarantee and provide support to one another to repay the loan. She does not sell on group meeting days and her picture was taken during her group meeting.

loans.use: To buy more bales of used clothes.

loans.name: Rhoida S.

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! This is 36-year-old Rhoida M. from Mbarali. She is married with 2 children, aged 10 and 14.  Rhoida has been running a rice milling machine since 2006. She works at the business for 5-8 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by her husband.  Rhoida  currently earns about 350 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 775 USD in order to renovate her office.  In the future, she plans to change her business.  Rhoida  thanks you for your support!

loans.name: Jenty

texts.en:
Jenty K. sells charcoal. Jenty is 45 years old and widowed. She has one child, who is in school. With the extra capital from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy more groundnut and make groundnut paste for sale.

loans.name: Mwajuma

texts.en:
Mwajuma H M. is 45 years old. She is a married woman with one child, aged 25 years. Mwajuma has been running a grocery business since 2008. She has two dependants who depend on her because they are orphans. She works seven days per week and 12 hours per day. She is requesting a loan of 275 USD in order to purchase additional stocks of rice, maize flour, wheat flour, sugar, salt, etc. In future she is planning to increase the quantity and range of the stock.

She thanks you for your support! SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. loans.name: Mpapai Group

texts.en:
Abdul K., age 40, is married with three children, ages 13, 2 and 6. He has sold second-hand shoes since 1998. He works daily from 8am until 9pm. He is able to earn a monthly profit of around $281.

This will be Abdul’s second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loan to increase his shoe business and has repaid the loan successfully. He now hopes for a loan to buy more shoes for good sales.

Abdul will share this loan with his loan group, Mpapai, which totals 17 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Abdul is the first one standing on the left.

loans.use: To increase his stock of shoes

loans.name: Ablaye

texts.fr: Ce habitant de la banlieue de Néma 2, sud de Ziguinchor, vend du poisson. Marié et pére de 3 enfants, il arrive à subvenir aux besoins familiaux avec cette activité. Il sollicite un prêt pour augmenter ses bénéfices en achetant beaucoup de poissons qu'il va revendre.
texts.en:
This resident of the Néma 2 suburb, south of Ziguinchor, sells fish. He is married and the father of 3 children. With this activity, he manages to provide for the family's needs. He is requesting a loan to increase his profit by buying a lot of fish that he will resell.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fish selling

loans.name: Merey  N.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 25 year-old Merey L. from Mbarali. She is married with 3 children, between the ages of 1 and 7.  Merey has been running an electrical appliance business since 2006. Her business is  to buy electrical appliances on wholesale basis and sell them retail.

She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by her husband.  Merey currently earns about 120 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 650 USD in order to purchase more appliances in bulk for reselling. In the future, she plans to expand her business by adding more appliances.  Merey  thanks you for your support!

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en: Blessing E. is 26 years old and married with a child. She lives in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria. Her husband is a commercial driver. She sells drinks, foodstuffs and provisions. She hopes to own a supermarket in future. She needs a loan of N30, 000 to purchase more provisions and foodstuffs to sell. She says thank you to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and provisions to sell

loans.name: Lucie

Elle cultive dans le village de  HÊTIN SOTA  de la vallée de l’Ouémé et est membre du groupement   GF DJIDJOHO DE HÊTIN SOTA  situé à proximité de la source thermale de dangbo ; elle vend aussi du maïs. Leurs spéculations principales sont la culture du maïs, du piment, des légumes, du gombo, de la tomate et du manioc qui sont des aliments de grande consommation au Bénin. Le problème de ces habitants riverains du fleuve est que, en période de crue, ils n’ont plus d’activité et dépensent tout le revenu issu de la campagne écoulée à la consommation. A la décrue ils n’ont plus d’argent pour payer la main d’œuvre indispensable pour emblaver la superficie à eux disponible.  La pratique dans le milieu qui consiste au bradage des récoltes ne les sécurise pas et les runes d’avantage. Cette pratique est la vente à un prix dérisoire de la récolte future à un nanti pour disposer de la somme nécessaire aux travaux champêtres. Fatigués de cette pratique elle a sollicité un prêt de 110 000 FCFA pour l’exploitation d’environ 1,5hectares des spéculations susse indiquées.
texts.en:
Born around 1963 in Hetin Dogodo, in the township of Dangbo, Mrs. Lucie B. is married and the mother of 5 children, of whom one is enrolled in school. She is a farmer in the village of Hetin Sota in the valley of the Ouémé River and is a member of the group GF Djidjoho of Hetin Sota, located near the hot springs of Dangbo. She also sells corn (maize).

The inhabitants of this village work as farmers when the river level is low. Their land is rich and gives them a good harvest. Their principal crops are maize (corn), hot peppers, vegetables, okra, tomatoes, and manioc which are staple foods in Benin. The problem for these people who dwell along the river is that when the river is in flood, they have no more work and spend all the money they earned during the last farming season on foodstuffs. When the waters recede, they have no money left to pay for laborers who are indispensible to them in sowing their land.

The custom of borrowing against the new harvest does not make them more secure and indeed leaves them worse off. They sell their future harvest at a laughable price to weathier persons so that they have the cash needed to do their farming. Weary of this practice, Lucie B. has requested a loan of 110,000 F CFA which will allow her to farm about 1.5 hectares, growing some of the aforementioned crops.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: cultivating 1.5 hectares in corn (maize) and hot peppers

loans.name: Decina Vicenta

texts.en:
Decina Vicenta G. G. is a member of the Azucenas (“White Lilies”) Village Bank. Decina lives with her partner and their two children. Decina has a stand in the April 12th Market in the city of Ayacucho where she sells  goods like rice and sugar, dried beans and grains. She works every day, and her children help her when they have free time.  Decina needs a loan of $650 to buy rice, sugar, fruitcake and milk.  Decina dreams of working to educate her children, of expanding her stand and of offering a wider variety of merchandise. 
Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow.

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, fruitcake and milk for sale

loans.name: Zelea M.

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Zelea G. from Mbarali. She is single but has 3 children, between the ages of 3 and 13. Zelea has been running a local restaurant, “Mama Lishe” since 2002.

When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is ‘restaurant’ or ‘café’, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all-local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savory banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.

She works at the business for 13-16 hours per day, 7 days per week and is assisted by her mother. She currently earns about 200USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400USD in order to purchase more rice in bulk. In the future, she plans to establish another business. Zelea thanks you for your support! ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more rice in bulk

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret H. sells bread at the bakery and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Margret is 31 years old and married. Her husband is a builder. She has seven children, who all go to school. With the extra profit generated from her loan, she hopes to be able to construct a house for accommodation.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services that are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To expand her bakery.

loans.name: Claudia

texts.en:
Claudia S. Y. is a member of the Azucenas (“White Lilies”) Village Bank.  Claudia is 33 years old and married with two children. Claudia has a hair salon in a rented location on a busy street in the city of Ayacucho. She also sells gifts and cosmetics. Claudia also sells a variety of shoes and rents out party dresses and wedding dresses.   Claudia needs a loan of $650 to buy shoes and sneakers.  Claudia’ s dreams are to build a house, to open a larger hair salon and to educate her children. 

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow.

loans.use: To buy shoes and sneakers for sale
