loans.name: Rene Milagros

texts.en:
Rene Milagros M. R. is a member of the Confianza (“Trust”) Village Bank. Rene is 37 years old and lives with her common-law husband and her three children. She and her husband sew curtains, reupholster furniture, and deal in other kinds of home décor. The couple works every day, and when there is a lot of demand for their services they hire help, too. Rene buys her materials in Lima and brings them to Ayacucho.  Rene needs a loan of $325 to buy a variety of fabric.  Rene’s dreams are to finish building her home, to expand her business, and to open other branches. 
 
Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow.

loans.use: To buy fabric

loans.name: Romana

texts.en:
This is Romana S Mruma. She is 28 years old. She is married with two children aged between 1 and 13 years. She has been running a grocery business since 1999. She is assisted by one employee and her husband in running this business. She is working seven days per week and 14 hours per day. In order to expand her business, she is requesting a loan of 1025 USD so that she can purchase additional stocks of rice, cooking oil, wheat flour, kerosene, sugar and other items for her grocery. In future she is planning to open another business. She thanks for your support!

loans.name: La Alianza Group

texts.en: La Alianza is a group from an extremely poor area in San Pedro, Dominican Republic. In this group, many of the women have already received loans and have their own small business. Dionicia S. is the group representative, and a great example of the power of micro-credit. She came to Esperanza International with no form of income and was living in extreme poverty. Dionicia is the mother of 4 older children, and had to give everything she had just to feed them. As her children got older and she started to have a little more time she realized she wanted something different from her life, and knew she had to do something about it. She then applied for a small loan so she could start her own small store, which she started as a small stand in her neighborhood. She sold simple things like candy, rice, and other cheaper items. She worked hard and was able to increase her business to the point today where she has her own small store! She is finally making some good money, and is happy with what she is doing. She can finally save money and help out her children when they need it. She finally feels like she can provide, and feels like she has something of her own. She is a great story of success, and is continuing to increase her business. She hopes to keep on increasing in size and hopes to have a giant store someday.

loans.use: This loan will be used to purchase food for her store

They sell their future harvest at a laughable price to weathier persons so that they have the cash needed to do their farming. Weary of this practice, Joséphine D. H. has requested a loan of 110,000 F CFA which will allow her to farm about 1.5 hectares, growing some of the aforementioned crops.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: cultivating 1.5 hectares in corn (maize) and hot peppers

loans.name: Upendo

texts.en:
This is Upendo J K.. She is a married woman with two children. She is 31 years old and her childen are 6 and 8 years old respectively. She is running a used cloth business. her husband is giving her enough support to run this business. She works in her business 10 hours a day and 6 days per week. She is capable of making a monthly profit of about 250 USD and she is requesting a loan of 500 USD in order to purchase additional stock of used cloth. She is planning to open another business. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of used cloth.

loans.name: Bodé Agathe

texts.fr: Née vers 1983 à  Damè  dans la commune de DANGBO, dame A. Bodé Agathe   est mariée et mère de 1enfant. Elle cultive dans le village de  HÊTIN SOTA  de la vallée de l’Ouémé et est membre du groupement    GF WANGNIME  DE HÊTIN SOTA  situé à proximité de la source thermale de dangbo ; elle vend aussi de la farine et de la boisson. Les habitants de ce village font les travaux champêtres à la décrue du fleuve ouémé. Leurs terres sont riches et les offrent un bon rendement.  Leurs spéculations principales sont la culture du maïs, du piment, des légumes, du gombo, de la tomate et du manioc qui sont des aliments de grande consommation au Bénin. Le problème de ces habitants riverains du fleuve est que, en période de crue, ils n’ont plus d’activité et dépensent tout le revenu issu de la campagne écoulée à la consommation. A la décrue ils n’ont plus d’argent pour payer la main d’œuvre indispensable pour emblaver la superficie à eux disponible.  La pratique dans le milieu qui consiste au bradage des récoltes ne les sécurise pas et les runes d’avantage. Cette pratique est la vente à un prix dérisoire de la récolte future à un nanti pour disposer de la somme nécessaire aux travaux champêtres. Fatigués de cette pratique elle a sollicité un prêt de 110 000 FCFA pour l’exploitation d’environ 1,5hectares des spéculations susse indiquées.
texts.en:
Born around 1983 in Damè in the township of Dangbo, Mrs. Bodé Agathe A. is married and the mother of 1 child. She is a farmer in the village of Hetin Sota in the valley of the Ouémé River and is a member of the group GF Wangnime of Hetin Sota, located near the hot springs of Dangbo. She also sells flour and drinks.

The inhabitants of this village work as farmers when the river level is low. Their land is rich and gives them a good harvest. Their principal crops are maize (corn), hot peppers, vegetables, okra, tomatoes, and manioc which are staple foods in Benin. The problem for these people who dwell along the river is that when the river is in flood, they have no more work and spend all the money they earned during the last farming season on foodstuffs. When the waters recede, they have no money left to pay for laborers who are indispensible to them in sowing their land.

The custom of borrowing against the new harvest does not make them more secure and indeed leaves them worse off. They sell their future harvest at a laughable price to weathier persons so that they have the cash needed to do their farming. Weary of this practice, Bodé Agathe A. has requested a loan of 110,000 F CFA which will allow her to farm about 1.5 hectares, growing some of the aforementioned crops.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: cultivating 1.5 hectares in corn (maize) and hot peppers

loans.name: Lidia

texts.en:
Lidia is a member of the Azucenas (“White Lilies”) Village Bank.  She is 32 years old and lives with her common-law husband and their two children. On Sundays, Lidia sells shoes from a mobile cart in the Las Americas Market. The rest of the week, she goes from house to house selling shoes on credit to friends and family members. She and her husband also have a car, which he drives as a taxi in the city of Ayacucho. Lidia needs a loan of $975 to buy different kinds of shoes.  Lidia’s dreams are to improve her business and for her children to graduate with professional degrees. 

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow.

loans.use: To buy different kinds of shoes
